{{Other uses}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2017}} {{Infobox person |name = Annie Oakley |image = Annie Oakley by Baker's Art Gallery c1880s-crop.jpg |image_size = |caption = Oakley in the 1880s |parents = Susan Wise Mosey (1830–1908), Jacob Mosey (1799–1866) |birth_name = Phoebe Ann Mosey |birth_date = {{birth date|1860|08|13}} |spouse = {{marriage|[[Frank E. Butler]]|1876|1926}} |birth_place = Near [[Willowdell, Ohio]], U.S. |death_date = {{Death date and age|1926|11|03|1860|08|13}} |death_place = [[Greenville, Ohio]], U.S. |signature = Annie Oakley Signature.svg }}
'''Annie Oakley''' (born '''Phoebe Ann Mosey'''; August 13, 1860 – November 3, 1926) was an American [[marksman|sharpshooter]] and [[exhibition shooting|exhibition shooter]]. Her amazing talent<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IK9J3H0S10wC&pg=PA55&dq=%22amazing+talent%22+%22sitting+bull%22 |title=Wild West Women (book)|page=55|last=Krohn|first=Katherine E. |publisher=Lerner Publications|year=2005|isbn=9780822526469}} "Sitting Bull was deeply moved by Annie's talent. He thought her ability with a gun was amazing."{{cite book|last=Wills|first=Charles M.|title=Annie Oakley: A Photographic Story of a Life (book)|year=2007|publisher=DK Children|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hTytOwAACAAJ&pg=PA71&dq=%22amazing+talent%22+%22sitting+bull%22|page=71|isbn=9780756629861}}</ref> first came to light when at age 15 she won a shooting match against traveling-show marksman [[Frank E. Butler]], whom she later married. The couple joined ''[[Buffalo Bill|Buffalo Bill's Wild West]]'' show a few years later. Oakley became a renowned international star, performing before royalty and heads of state.
Oakley also was variously known as "Miss Annie Oakley", "Little Sure Shot", "Little Miss Sure Shot", "Watanya Cicilla", "Phoebe Anne Oakley", "Mrs. Annie Oakley", "Mrs. Annie Butler", and "Mrs. Frank Butler". Her [[death certificate]] gives her name as "Annie Oakley Butler".<ref>{{cite web|title=Person Details for Annie Oakley Butler|url=https://familysearch.org/ark:/61903/1:1:X8K9-G86|website=FamilySearch.org}}</ref>
==Early life== Annie Oakley was born Phoebe Ann (Annie) Mosey<ref name=enddebate/><ref name=saysEdwards>{{cite web |url=http://www.annieoakleyfoundation.org/bio.html|title=Annie Oakley's Life and Career|last=Edwards|first=Bess |publisher=annieoakleyfoundation.org|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080314232045/http://www.annieoakleyfoundation.org/bio.html|archivedate=March 14, 2008|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=Mosesmyth/> on August 13, 1860, in a log cabin less than {{convert|2|mi|spell=in}} northwest of Woodland, now [[Willowdell, Ohio|Willowdell]], in [[Darke County, Ohio]], a rural western border county of Ohio.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ormiston.com/annieoakley/tales.html#YOUNG|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021015053658/http://www.ormiston.com/annieoakley/tales.html#YOUNG|archivedate=October 15, 2002|title=Tall Tales and the Truth|publisher=Annie Oakley Foundation}}</ref> Her birthplace is about five miles east of North Star. There is a stone-mounted plaque in the vicinity of the site, which was placed by the Annie Oakley Committee in 1981, 121 years after her birth.
Annie's parents were [[Religious Society of Friends|Quaker]]s of English descent from [[Hollidaysburg, Pennsylvania|Hollidaysburg]], [[Blair County, Pennsylvania]]: Susan Wise, age 18,<ref name="Wukovits">{{cite book|last=Wukovits|first=John|date=May 1997|title=Annie Oakley|series=Legends of the West|publisher=[[Chelsea House]]|isbn=978-0791039069}}</ref><ref name="Wills">{{cite book|last=Wills|first=Chuck|title=Annie Oakley|year=2007|publisher=[[Dorling Kindersley]]|location=London|isbn=978-0-7566-2997-7}}</ref> and Jacob Mosey, born 1799, age 49, married in 1848. They moved to a rented farm (later purchased with a mortgage) in [[Patterson Township, Darke County, Ohio]], sometime around 1855.
Born in 1860, Annie was the sixth of Jacob and Susan's nine children, and the fifth of the seven surviving.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/americanexperience/features/timeline/oakley/|title=Timeline: The Life of Annie Oakley|accessdate=June 15, 2015|quote=August 13, 1860: Annie Oakley is born Phoebe Ann Moses, on the family farm in Darke County, Ohio, fifth ...|work=[[American Experience]]|publisher=[[Public Broadcasting Service]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150502042159/http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/americanexperience/features/timeline/oakley/|archivedate=May 2, 2015|deadurl=no}}</ref> Her siblings were Mary Jane (1851–1867), Lydia (1852–1882), Elizabeth (1855–1881), Sarah Ellen (1857–1939), Catherine (1859–1859), John (1861–1949), Hulda (1864–1934) and a stillborn infant brother in 1865. Annie's father, who had fought in the [[War of 1812]], became an invalid from [[hypothermia]] during a blizzard in late 1865 and died of [[pneumonia]] in early 1866 at age 66.<ref>{{cite book|last=Riley|first=Glenda|title=The Life and Legacy of Annie Oakley |publisher = [[University of Oklahoma Press]]|year=1994|page=5|isbn=9780806126562}}</ref> Her mother later married Daniel Brumbaugh, had one more child, Emily (1868–1937), and was widowed for a second time.
Because of poverty following the death of her father, Annie did not regularly attend school as a child, although she did attend later in childhood and in adulthood.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kasper|first=Shirl|title=Annie Oakley|year=1992|publisher=[[University of Oklahoma Press]]|isbn=978-0-8061-2418-6|pages=6, 20}}</ref> On March 15, 1870, at age nine, she was admitted to the Darke County Infirmary along with her sister Sarah Ellen. According to her autobiography, she was put in the care of the infirmary's superintendent, Samuel Crawford Edington, and his wife Nancy, who taught her to sew and decorate. Beginning in the spring of 1870, she was "bound out" to a local family to help care for their infant son, on the false promise of fifty cents a week and an education. The couple had originally wanted someone who could pump water, cook, and who was bigger. She spent about two years in near slavery to them, enduring mental and physical abuse. One time, the wife put Annie out in the freezing cold without shoes, as a punishment because she had fallen asleep over some darning.<ref>{{cite video|people=Freifeld, Riva (director and producer)|year=2006|title=The American Experience: Annie Oakley|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/americanexperience/features/cast-crew/oakley-credits/|publisher=WGBH|location=Boston, MA}}</ref> Annie referred to them as "the wolves". Even in her autobiography, she never revealed the couple's real names.<ref>Whiting, Jim. What's so great about Annie Oakley. Mitchell Lane Publishers. Delaware, 2007.</ref>
According to biographer Glenda Riley, "the wolves" could have been the Studabaker family,<ref>{{cite book|last=Riley|first=Glenda|title=The Life and Legacy of Annie Oakley|publisher=[[University of Oklahoma Press]]|year=1994|page=7}}</ref> but the 1870 U.S. Census suggests they were the Abram Boose family of neighboring [[Preble County, Ohio|Preble County]].<ref name=cen1870en>{{cite web|url=http://www.family-forest.net/photos/AnnieMoseyCensus1870Enlarged.jpg|title=AnnieMoseyCensus1870Enlarged|editor=Billene Statler Nicol|format=JPG|year=2010|accessdate=August 9, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140811025310/http://www.family-forest.net/photos/AnnieMoseyCensus1870Enlarged.jpg|archivedate=August 11, 2014|deadurl=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=fscen1870>{{cite web|url=https://familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.3.1/TH-266-11929-69872-17?cc=1438024|title=TH-266-11929-69872-17|publisher=[[FamilySearch]]|year=1870|work=U.S. Census, Harrison Township, Preble County, Ohio|page=54}}</ref> Around the spring of 1872, Annie ran away from "the wolves". According to biographer Shirl Kasper, it was only at this point that Annie met and lived with the Edingtons, returning to her mother's home around the age of 15.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kasper|first=Shirl|title=Annie Oakley|publisher=[[University of Oklahoma Press]]|year=1992|isbn=0-8061-2418-0|pages=6, 7|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=g1CqL48DUo0C&printsec=frontcover&dq=annie+oakley+shirl+kasper}}</ref> Annie's mother married a third time, to Joseph Shaw, on October 25, 1874.{{citation needed|date=October 2014|reason=Needs cite for date of mother's marriage to Shaw}}
Annie began trapping before the age of seven, and shooting and hunting by age eight, to support her siblings and her widowed mother. She sold the hunted game to locals in [[Greenville, Ohio|Greenville]], such as shopkeepers Charles and G. Anthony Katzenberger, who shipped it to hotels in Cincinnati and other cities.<ref>{{cite book | last = Riley | first = Glenda | title = The Life and Legacy of Annie Oakley | publisher = [[University of Oklahoma Press]] | date = 1994 | page = 11}}</ref> She also sold the game to restaurants and hotels in northern Ohio. Her skill paid off the mortgage on her mother's farm when Annie was 15.<ref name=Dorchester>{{cite web |url=http://www.dorchesterlibrary.org/library/aoakley.html |title=Annie Oakley |publisher=Dorchester County Public Library, Cambridge, MD}}</ref>
==Debut and marriage== [[File:The Amateur Circus at Nutley by Peter Newall 1894.jpg|thumb|''The Amateur Circus at Nutley'' (1894) by American illustrator Peter Newell. The scene depicted in the center is of Annie Oakley, standing on horseback, demonstrating her shooting ability.]]
Annie soon became well known throughout the region. On Thanksgiving Day 1875,<ref name=PBS>{{cite web|author=<!--none given-->|title=Biography: Frank Butler|url=http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/americanexperience/features/oakley-butler/|work=pbs.org|accessdate=April 24, 2018}}</ref> the Baughman & Butler shooting act was being performed in [[Cincinnati, Ohio|Cincinnati]]. Traveling show marksman and former dog trainer [[Frank E. Butler]] (1847–1926), an Irish immigrant, placed a $100 bet per side ({{Inflation|US|100|1875|fmt=eq}}) with Cincinnati hotel owner Jack Frost that Butler could beat any local fancy shooter.<ref name="CL">[http://longford.rootsireland.ie/ Longford Genealogy], Retrieved October 8, 2014.</ref> The hotelier arranged a shooting match between Butler and the 15-year-old Annie, saying, "The last opponent Butler expected was a five-foot-tall 15-year-old girl named Annie."<ref name=PBS/> After missing on his 25th shot, Butler lost the match and the bet. Another account says that Butler hit on his last shot, but the bird fell dead about two feet beyond the boundary line.<ref name="CE">{{cite news|url=https://www.cincinnati.com/story/news/history/2014/07/20/did-annie-oakley-shooting-contest-happen-in-cincinnati/12913819/|title= Did Annie Oakley shooting contest happen in Cincinnati?|author=Suess, Jeff|newspaper=[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]|date=July 20, 2014|accessdate=April 24, 2018}}</ref> He soon began courting Annie and they married. They did not have children.<ref name=PBS/>
According to a modern-day account in ''[[The Cincinnati Enquirer]]'', it is possible that the shooting match may have taken place in 1881 and not 1875.<ref name="CE"/> It appears the time of the event was never recorded. Biographer Shirl Kasper states the shooting match took place in the spring of 1881 near Greenville, possibly in North Star as mentioned by Butler during interviews in 1903 and 1924. Other sources seem to coincide with the [[North Fairmount, Cincinnati|North Fairmount]] location near Cincinnati if the event occurred in 1881.<ref name="CE"/> The Annie Oakley Center Foundation mentions Oakley visiting her married sister Lydia Stein at her home near Cincinnati in 1875.<ref name="AOF">[http://www.annieoakleycenterfoundation.com/faq.html Annie Oakley Center Foundation], Retrieved October 2, 2014.</ref> That information is incorrect as Lydia didn't marry Joseph C. Stein until March 19, 1877.<ref name="FS">[https://familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.1.1/XDF7-123 FamilySearch], Retrieved October 2, 2014. {{Dead link|date=April 2018}}</ref> Although speculation, it is most likely that Oakley and her mother visited Lydia in 1881 as she was seriously ill from [[tuberculosis]].<ref name="GENI">[https://www.geni.com/people/Lydia-Stein/6000000020692137376 Geni], Retrieved April 24, 2018.</ref> The Bevis House hotel was still being operated by Martin Bevis and W. H. Ridenour in 1875. It opened around 1860 after the building was previously used as a pork packaging facility. Jack Frost didn't obtain management of the hotel until 1879.<ref name="CE"/><ref name="CINCY">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dW-52BWC4LoC&pg=PA209&lpg=PA209|publisher=State of Ohio Works Progress Administration|title=Cincinnati: A Guide to the Queen City and its Neighbors|date=May 1943|page=209}}</ref> The Baughman & Butler shooting act first appeared on the pages of ''The Cincinnati Enquirer'' in 1880. They signed with [[Sells Brothers Circus]] in 1881 and made an appearance at the Coliseum Opera House later that year.<ref name="CE"/>
Regardless of the actual date of the shooting match, Oakley and Butler were married a year afterward. A certificate on file with the [[Archives of Ontario]], Registration Number 49594, reports that Butler and Oakley were wed on June 20, 1882, in [[Windsor, Ontario]].<ref name="AO">Archives of Ontario via Ancestry.com (Ontario, Canada, Marriages 1801-1928), Retrieved on October 1, 2014.</ref> Many sources say the marriage took place on August 23, 1876, in Cincinnati,<ref name="AOF"/> but no recorded certificate validates that date. A possible reason for the contradictory dates is that Butler's divorce from his first wife, Henrietta Saunders, was not yet final in 1876. An 1880 U.S. Federal Census record shows Saunders as married.<ref name="ANC1880">[http://search.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/sse.dll?rank=1&new=1&MSAV=0&gss=angs-g&gsfn=henrietta&gsln=butler&mswpn__ftp=Camden%2c+Camden%2c+New+Jersey%2c+USA&mswpn=7420&mswpn_PInfo=8-|0|1652393|0|2|3244|33|0|468|7420|0|&msbdy=1854&uidh=9rd&pcat=ROOT_CATEGORY&h=49520049&db=1880usfedcen&indiv=1&ml_rpos=1 Ancestry.com, 1880 U.S. Federal Census], Retrieved October 7, 2014.</ref> Sources mentioning Butler's first wife as Elizabeth are inaccurate; Elizabeth was his granddaughter, her father being Edward F. Butler.<ref name="ANC1900">[http://search.ancestry.com/cgi-bin/sse.dll?rank=1&new=1&MSAV=0&msT=1&gss=angs-g&gsfn=elizabeth&gsln=butler&mswpn__ftp=Camden%2c+Camden%2c+New+Jersey%2c+USA&mswpn=7420&mswpn_PInfo=8-|0|1652393|0|2|3244|33|0|468|7420|0|&msbdy=1895&uidh=9rd&pcat=ROOT_CATEGORY&h=44952628&db=1900usfedcen&indiv=1&ml_rpos=2 Ancestry.com, 1900 U.S. Federal Census], Retrieved October 7, 2014.</ref> Throughout Oakley's show-business career, the public was often led to believe that she was five to six years younger than she was. The later marriage date would have better supported her fictional age.<ref name="AOF"/>
==Career and touring== {{Quote box|align=right|width=30%|quote="Aim at the high mark and you will hit it. No, not the first time, not the second time and maybe not the third. But keep on aiming and keep on shooting for only practice will make you perfect. Finally you'll hit the bull's-eye of success."|source=Annie Oakley exhibit at the [[National Cowgirl Museum and Hall of Fame]] in [[Fort Worth, Texas]]}}
Annie and Frank Butler lived in Cincinnati for a time. Oakley, the stage name she adopted when she and Frank began performing together,<ref name=Mosesmyth/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/americanexperience/films/oakley/|title=Annie Oakley|accessdate=April 7, 2009|quote=Narrator: Butler was Annie's ticket out of Greenville. They soon married. For the next six years, while Butler and his new shooting partner John Graham performed on the variety circuit, Annie stayed in the background. That was about to change [when] Butler and Graham were playing a theater in Springfield, Ohio, when John Graham suddenly fell ill. Annie filled in, holding the targets. That night Frank kept missing – until a jeering spectator shouted, "Let the girl shoot!" Frank obliged. Annie hit the targets every time – much to the delight of the raucous crowd. Mrs. Butler took a stage name, borrowed from her paternal grandmother – Annie Oakley.|work=[[American Experience]]|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090406085146/http://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/oakley/|archivedate=April 6, 2009|deadurl=no}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ormiston.com/annieoakley/tales.html#NAME |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021015053658/http://www.ormiston.com/annieoakley/tales.html#NAME|archivedate=October 15, 2002 |title=Tall Tales and the Truth: Born Phoebe Anne Oakley Mozee?|publisher=web.archive.org}} (the answer is no: "Her mother, Susan, named her Phoebe Ann…"; her father Jacob is surnamed "Mosey" in the [[National Archives]] War of 1812 military records; "In the 1870 Census, Annie is listed as Ann Mosey" – but, several other surname spellings appeared later. "The professional name Oakley was assumed in 1882, when Annie began to perform with Frank Butler; …")</ref> is believed to have been taken from the city's neighborhood of [[Oakley, Cincinnati|Oakley]], where they resided. Some people believe she took on the name because that was the name of the man who had paid her train fare when she was a child.<ref name="AOF"/>
[[File:Annie Oakley - Full length photograph circa 1899.jpg|thumb|upright|left|Oakley c. 1899]]
They joined ''[[Buffalo Bill's Wild West]]'' in 1885. At five feet tall, Oakley was given the nickname of "Watanya Cicilla" by fellow performer [[Sitting Bull]], rendered "Little Sure Shot" in the public advertisements.
During her first engagement with the Buffalo Bill show, Oakley experienced a tense professional rivalry with rifle sharpshooter [[Lillian Smith (entertainer)|Lillian Smith]]. Smith was eleven years younger than Oakley, age 15 at the time she joined the show in 1886, which may have been a primary reason for Oakley to alter her actual age in later years due to Smith's press coverage becoming as favorable as hers.<ref name="LSTOT">{{cite journal|url=http://www.historynet.com/lillian-smith-the-on-target-california-girl.htm|title=Lillian Smith: The On-Target 'California Girl'|magazine=Wild West|author=Bricklin, Julia|date=November 25, 2014|accessdate=April 24, 2018}}</ref> Oakley temporarily left the Buffalo Bill show but returned two years later, after Smith departed, in time for the [[Exposition Universelle (1889)|Paris Exposition of 1889]].<ref name="AmExAOBio"/> This three-year tour only cemented Oakley as America's first female star. She earned more than any other performer in the show, except for [[Buffalo Bill|"Buffalo Bill" Cody]] himself. She also performed in many shows on the side for extra income.<ref name="AmExAOBio"/>
In Europe, she performed for [[Queen Victoria]] of the United Kingdom, [[King Umberto I]] of Italy, President [[Marie François Sadi Carnot]] of France and other crowned heads of state. Oakley supposedly shot the ashes off a cigarette held by the newly crowned German [[Kaiser Wilhelm II]] at his request.<ref name=Kaiser>{{cite web|url=http://www.ormiston.com/annieoakley/tales.html#KAISER |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021015053658/http://www.ormiston.com/annieoakley/tales.html#KAISER|archivedate=October 15, 2002 |title=Tall Tales and the Truth: Did she shoot the Kaiser's cigarette?|publisher=Annie Oakley Foundation at web.archive.org}}</ref>
[[File:Miss-Annie-Oakley-peerless-wing-shot.jpg|thumb|upright|''Wild West Show'' poster]]
From 1892 to 1904, Oakley and Butler made their home in [[Nutley, New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite news|author=Beglin, Julie|title=In Nutley, Mementos of a Very Straight Shooter|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/02/23/nyregion/in-nutley-mementos-of-a-very-straight-shooter.html|accessdate=April 24, 2018|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=February 23, 1997}}</ref>
Oakley promoted the service of women in combat operations for the [[United States armed forces]]. She wrote a letter to President [[William McKinley]] on April 5, 1898, "offering the government the services of a company of 50 'lady sharpshooters' who would provide their own arms and ammunition should the U.S. go to war with Spain."<ref name="archives.gov">The [[National Archives and Records Administration]] (NARA). [https://www.archives.gov/research/recover/example-02.html Letter to President William McKinley from Annie Oakley]. Retrieved January 24, 2008.</ref>
The [[Spanish–American War]] did occur, but Oakley's offer was not accepted. [[Theodore Roosevelt]], did, however, name his volunteer cavalry the "[[Rough Riders]]" after the "Buffalo Bill's Wild West and Congress of Rough Riders of the World" where Oakley was a major star.
The same year that McKinley was fatally shot by an assassin, 1901, Oakley was also badly injured in a train accident, but recovered after temporary paralysis and five spinal operations. She left the Buffalo Bill show and in 1902 began a less taxing acting career in a stage play written especially for her, ''The Western Girl''. Oakley played the role of Nancy Berry who used a pistol, a rifle and rope to outsmart a group of outlaws.<ref name="Wukovits"/>
Throughout her career, it is believed that Oakley taught more than 15,000 women how to use a gun. Oakley believed strongly that it was crucial for women to learn how to use a gun, as not only a form of physical and mental exercise, but also to defend themselves.<ref name="Wills"/> She said: "I would like to see every woman know how to handle guns as naturally as they know how to handle babies."
== ''The Little Sure Shot of the Wild West (Annie Oakley)'' == [[File:Annie Oakley shooting glass balls, 1894.ogv|thumb|[[Annie Oakley (1894 film)|''Annie Oakley'']], 1894, an "exhibition of rifle shooting at glass balls, etc.", in an Edison Kinetoscope movie]]
Buffalo Bill was friends with [[Thomas Edison]], and Edison built the world's largest electrical power plant at the time for the ''Wild West Show''.<ref name=dorchester /> Buffalo Bill and 15 of his show Indians appeared in two Kinetoscopes filmed September 24, 1894.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.mbrsmi/edmp.4025 |title=Buffalo dance / Thomas A. Edison, Inc. ; producer, W.K.L. Dickson. |publisher=Library of Congress Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division |date=May 13, 1994 |accessdate=October 15, 2009}}</ref>
In 1894, Oakley and Butler performed in Edison's [[Kinetoscope]] film [[Annie Oakley (1894 film)|''The "Little Sure Shot of the Wild West," an exhibition of rifle shooting at glass balls, etc.'']]<ref>As titled and described by Raff & Gammon, Price list of films, ca. June 1895, p. 1 [MI].</ref> which was filmed November 1, 1894 in [[Edison's Black Maria]] studio by William Heise.<ref>It lasted 21 seconds at 30 frames and 39 feet.</ref><ref>[http://rs6.loc.gov/cgi-bin/query/r?ammem/papr:@filreq(@field(NUMBER+@band(edmp+4030))+@field(COLLID+edison)) DIGITAL ID edmp 4030 http://hdl.loc.gov/loc.mbrsmi/edmp.4030 Library of Congress Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division Washington, D. C. 20540 USA].</ref> It was the eleventh film made after commercial showings began on April 14, 1894.<ref>[http://rs6.loc.gov/ammem/edhtml/edmvchrn.html Chronological Title List of Edison Motion Pictures] - Library of Congress Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division Washington, D. C. 20540 USA</ref>
==Shooting prowess== [[File:Annie Oakley shooting over her shoulder using a hand mirror..jpg|thumb|left|Annie Oakley shooting over her shoulder using a hand mirror.|382x382px]]
Biographers, such as Shirl Kasper, repeat Oakley's own story about her very first shot at the age of eight. "I saw a squirrel run down over the grass in front of the house, through the orchard and stop on a fence to get a hickory nut." Taking a rifle from the house, she fired at the squirrel, writing later that, "It was a wonderful shot, going right through the head from side to side".<ref>{{cite book|last=Kasper|first=Shirl|title=Annie Oakley|publisher=[[University of Oklahoma Press]]|year=1992|isbn=0-8061-2418-0|page=4|url=https://books.google.com/?id=g1CqL48DUo0C&pg=PA3}}</ref> The ''[[Encyclopædia Britannica]]'' notes that:<blockquote>Oakley never failed to delight her audiences, and her feats of marksmanship were truly incredible. At 30 paces she could split a playing card held edge-on, she hit dimes tossed into the air, she shot cigarettes from her husband's lips, and, a playing card being thrown into the air, she riddled it before it touched the ground.<ref>''Encyclopædia Britannica'', article on Annie Oakley.</ref> </blockquote>
R. A. Koestler-Grack reports that, on March 19, 1884, she was being watched by [[Chief Sitting Bull]] when:<blockquote>Oakley playfully skipped on stage, lifted her rifle, and aimed the barrel at a burning candle. In one shot, she snuffed out the flame with a whizzing bullet. Sitting Bull watched her knock corks off of bottles and slice through a cigar Butler held in his teeth.<ref>Koestler-Grack, RA., ''Annie Oakley'', Facts On File, Incorporated, Infobase Publishing, 2010, pp. 28–29.</ref> </blockquote>
== Libel cases == In 1904, sensational [[cocaine]] prohibition stories were selling well. Newspaper magnate [[William Randolph Hearst]] published a false story that Oakley had been arrested for stealing to support a cocaine habit. The woman actually arrested was a [[American burlesque|burlesque]] performer who told Chicago police that her name was Annie Oakley.
Most of the newspapers that printed the story had relied on the Hearst article, and they immediately retracted it with apologies upon learning of the libelous error. Hearst, however, tried to avoid paying the anticipated court judgments of $20,000 (equivalent to ${{Inflation|US|20000|1904|fmt=c}} in 2017) by sending an investigator to Darke County, Ohio with the intent of collecting reputation-smearing gossip from Oakley's past. The investigator found nothing.<ref name=pbs />
Oakley spent much of the next six years winning 54 of 55 [[libel]] lawsuits against newspapers. She collected less in judgments than the total of her legal expenses.<ref name=pbs>{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/amex/oakley/peopleevents/p_oakley.html |title=Annie Oakley (1860-1926) |publisher=pbs.org |date=February 14, 2006}}</ref>
== Later years and death == [[File:Annie Oakley NYWTS.jpg|thumb|left|Oakley in 1922|267x267px]]
In 1912, the Butlers built a brick [[ranch-style house]] in [[Cambridge, Maryland]]. It is known as the [[Annie Oakley House]] and was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 1996. In 1917, they moved to [[North Carolina]] and returned to public life.
She continued to set records into her sixties, and also engaged in extensive philanthropy for women's rights and other causes, including the support of young women she knew. She embarked on a comeback and intended to star in a feature-length silent movie. She hit 100 clay targets in a row from {{convert|16|yd}} at age 62 in a 1922 shooting contest in [[Pinehurst, North Carolina]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lkwdpl.org/wihohio/oakl-ann.htm |title=Annie Oakley |publisher=lkwdpl.org Women in History |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120713141105/http://lkwdpl.org/wihohio/oakl-ann.htm |archivedate=July 13, 2012 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
In late 1922, the couple were in a car accident that forced her to wear a steel brace on her right leg. She eventually performed again after more than a year of recovery, and she set records in 1924.<ref name=dorchester>{{cite web |url=http://www.dorchesterlibrary.org/library/aoakley.html |title=Annie Oakley |publisher=dorchesterlibrary.org Dorchester County Public Library}}</ref>
Her health declined in 1925 and she died of [[pernicious anemia]] in [[Greenville, Ohio]] at the age of 66 on November 3, 1926.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=Champion Rifle Shot. Chipped Ash From Wilhelm's Cigarette. Bullets Lifted Home Mortgage. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1926/11/14/archives/annie-oakley-known-by-gun-champion-rifle-shot-a-sufficient-address.html |quote= |work=The New York Times |date=November 14, 1926 |accessdate=April 8, 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |title=Little Sureshot |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,722700,00.html |quote=As it must to all men, Death came to Mrs. Annie Oakley. Butler, 66, most marked markswoman in history, at Greenville, Ohio, after long illness. |work=[[Time magazine]] |date=November 15, 1966 |accessdate=April 8, 2009 }}</ref> Her body was cremated in Cincinnati two days later and the ashes buried at Brock Cemetery, near Greenville.<ref name="CE" /><ref name=OhGraves>{{cite web |author=<!--none given--> |title=Famous Ohio Gravesites |url=http://www.ohiotraveler.com/Venue%20Files/famous_ohio_gravesites.htm |accessdate=May 22, 2013 |work=ohiotraveler.com}}</ref><ref name="AmExAOBio">{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/americanexperience/features/biography/oakley-annie/|title=WGBH American Experience . Annie Oakley - PBS|publisher=}}</ref>
Butler was so grieved by her death, according to B. Haugen, that he stopped eating and died 18 days later in Michigan, and his body was buried next to Oakley's ashes.<ref>{{ cite book | last = Kasper | first = Shirl | title = Annie Oakley | publisher = [[University of Oklahoma Press]] | date = 1992 | isbn = 0-8061-2418-0 | pages = 243–244 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=g1CqL48DUo0C&pg=PA3#v=onepage&q&f=false }}</ref><ref>Haugen, B., ''Annie Oakley: American Sharpshooter'', Capstone, 2006, p. 88.</ref> Kasper reports that the death certificate said that Butler died of "senility". One rumor claims that Oakley's ashes were placed in one of her prized trophies and laid next to Butler's body in his coffin prior to burial.<ref name="RA">[http://www.roadsideamerica.com/tip/3527 Roadside America.com], Retrieved October 1, 2014.</ref> Both body and ashes were interred in the cemetery on Thanksgiving Day, November 25, 1926.<ref name="AS">[https://books.google.com/books?id=9Jpa_xsZ5s4C&pg=PA89&lpg=PA89&dq=annie+oakley+buried+thanksgiving+1926 Brenda Haugen, ''Annie Oakley: American Sharpshooter'', page 89], Retrieved October 1, 2014.</ref>
After her death, her incomplete autobiography was given to stage comedian [[Fred Stone]],<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--none given--> |title=United States |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,722829,00.html |quote=From Greenville, Ohio, I received a heavy brown pasteboard box, which I carried to the stage of the Globe Theatre, Manhattan, and opened in the presence of a notary public. It contained several scrapbooks, with clippings, photographs, letters and a typed autobiography up to 1890 of my late friend, Annie Oakley Butler, ablest markswoman in history, who died last month. There was no letter of explanation but it seemed apparent that Annie Oakley, with whom I played in a circus some 20 years ago, wished me to be her Boswell. |work=[[Time magazine]] |date=December 6, 1926 |accessdate=April 8, 2009}}</ref> and it was discovered that her entire fortune had been spent on her family and her charities.<ref name="LLAO">[https://books.google.com/books?id=lzX5_UdMrtAC&pg=PA196&lpg=PA196&dq=frank+butler+1926+divorce+elizabeth+oakley Glenda Riley, ''The Life and Legacy of Annie Oakley'', page 196], Retrieved October 2, 2014.</ref>
A vast collection of Oakley's personal possessions, performance memorabilia, and firearms are on permanent exhibit in the Garst Museum and the National Annie Oakley Center in Greenville, Ohio.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://garstmuseum.org/|title=Garst Museum - Home of the Annie Oakley Center|publisher=}}</ref> She has been inducted into the Trapshooting Hall of Fame, the [[National Cowgirl Museum and Hall of Fame]] in [[Fort Worth, Texas]], the [[National Women's Hall of Fame]], the [[Ohio Women's Hall of Fame]], and the [[New Jersey Hall of Fame]].
== Surname == There are a number of variations given for Oakley's family name, Mosey. Many biographers and other references give the name as "Moses".<ref name=aocffaq>{{ cite web | url = http://www.annieoakleycenterfoundation.com/faq.html | title = Frequently Asked Questions about Annie Oakley | publisher = Annie Oakley Center Foundation | accessdate = August 9, 2014 }}</ref> Although the [[1860 United States Census|1860 U.S. Census]] shows the family name as "Mauzy", this is considered an error introduced by the census taker.<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://family-forest.net/photos/Mosey1860Census.jpg | title = Mosey1860Census | editor = Billene Statler Nicol | format = JPG | date = 2010 | accessdate = July 31, 2014 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140731110025/http://family-forest.net/photos/Mosey1860Census.jpg | archivedate = July 31, 2014 | deadurl = yes }}</ref><ref name=kasper23>{{ cite book | last = Kasper | first = Shirl | title = Annie Oakley | publisher = [[University of Oklahoma Press]] | date = 1992 | isbn = 0-8061-2418-0 | page = 23 | url = https://books.google.com/?id=g1CqL48DUo0C&pg=PA3#v=onepage&q=mauzy&f=false }}</ref> Oakley's name appears as "Ann Mosey" in the [[1870 United States Census|1870 U.S. Census]]<ref name=cen1870en /><ref name=fscen1870 /> and "Mosey" is engraved on her father's headstone and appears in his military record; "Mosey" is the official spelling by the Annie Oakley Foundation, maintained by her living relatives.<ref name=enddebate>{{cite web |url=http://www.annieoakleyfoundation.org/newsletters/no14.pdf |title=We Hope "Mosey" Ends the Debate |work=Taking Aim Newsletter |publisher=annieoakleyfoundation.org |date=Summer 2003 |format=PDF |access-date=August 9, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140812101434/http://www.annieoakleyfoundation.org/newsletters/no14.pdf |archive-date=August 12, 2014 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=Mosesmyth>{{cite web|url=http://www.ormiston.com/annieoakley/tales.html#NAME |title=Archived copy |accessdate=January 11, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021015053658/http://www.ormiston.com/annieoakley/tales.html#NAME |archivedate=October 15, 2002 |df= }}</ref><ref name=talltales>{{cite web |url=http://www.ormiston.com/annieoakley/tales.html#NAME |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20021015053658/http://www.ormiston.com/annieoakley/tales.html#NAME |archivedate=October 15, 2002 |title=Tall Tales and the Truth: Born Phoebe Anne Oakley Mozee?| publisher=web.archive.org}} (the answer is "no": "Her mother, Susan, named her Phoebe Ann…"; her father Jacob is surnamed "Mosey" in the [[National Archives]] War of 1812 military records; "In the 1870 Census, Annie is listed as Ann Mosey"{{spaced ndash}}but, several other surname spellings appeared later. "The professional name Oakley was assumed in 1882, when Annie began to perform with Frank Butler; it was not a family name.")</ref> The spelling "Mosie" has also appeared.
According to Kasper, Oakley insisted that her family name be spelled "Mozee", leading to arguments with her brother John. Kasper speculates that Oakley may have considered "Mozee" to be a more [[phonetic spelling]]. There is also popular speculation that young Oakley had been teased about her name by other children.<ref name=kasper23 />
Prior to their [[double wedding]] in March 1884, both Oakley's brother John and one of her sisters, Hulda, changed their surnames to "Moses".<ref name=enddebate /><ref name=talltales />
== Eponym == During her lifetime, the theatre business began referring to complimentary tickets as "Annie Oakleys". Such tickets traditionally have holes punched into them (to prevent them from being resold), reminiscent of the playing cards Oakley shot through during her sharpshooting act.{{Citation needed|date=March 2018}}
== Representations on stage, literature and screen ==
{{in popular culture|date=October 2018}} * In 1935, [[Barbara Stanwyck]] played Oakley in a fictionalized film called ''[[Annie Oakley (1935 film)|Annie Oakley]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0026073/|title=Annie Oakley (1935)|last=|first=|date=|website=IMDb|access-date=}}</ref> * The 1946 [[Irving Berlin]] [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] musical ''[[Annie Get Your Gun (musical)|Annie Get Your Gun]]'' is loosely based on her life.<ref>Bloom, Ken and Vlastnik, Frank (2004). ''Broadway Musicals: The 101 Greatest Shows of all Time.'' New York: Black Dog & Leventhal Publishers, p. 13. {{ISBN|1-57912-390-2}}</ref> The original stage production starred [[Ethel Merman]], who also starred in the 1966 revival. ** A [[Annie Get Your Gun (film)|1950 film]] version of the musical starred [[Betty Hutton]] and [[Howard Keel]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0042200/?ref_=nm_knf_i1|title=Annie Get Your Gun (1950)|last=|first=|date=|website=IMDb|access-date=}}</ref> ** Several years after headlining the 1948 national tour, Broadway legend [[Mary Martin]] returned to the role for a 1957 [[NBC]] [[television]] special that also featured [[John Raitt]] as Frank Butler.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0182719/|title=Annie Get Your Gun (1957)|last=|first=|date=|website=IMDb|access-date=}}</ref> * From 1954 to 1956, [[Gail Davis]] played Oakley in the ''[[Annie Oakley (TV series)|Annie Oakley]]'' television series.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0046578/|title=Annie Oakley (TV Series 1954–1957)|last=|first=|date=|website=IMDb|access-date=}}</ref> * In 1976, [[Geraldine Chaplin]] portrayed Oakley in ''[[Buffalo Bill and the Indians, or Sitting Bull's History Lesson]]''. * In 1983, New American Library published The Secret Annie Oakley, by Marcy Heidish, which established that her husband Frank Butler was not an envious competitor, as portrayed in the Broadway musical, but was her greatest support from the day they met.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/1983/0803/080303.html|title=Annie Oakley tale outshines other new novels; The Secret Annie Oakley, by Marcy Heidish. New York: New American Library. 233 pp. $14.95.|first=Gay Andrews|last=Dillin|date=August 3, 1983|publisher=|via=Christian Science Monitor}}</ref> * In 1985, [[Jamie Lee Curtis]] portrayed Oakley in ''[[Tall Tales & Legends]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088728/|title="Tall Tales & Legends" Annie Oakley (TV Episode 1985)|last=|first=|date=|website=IMDb|access-date=}}</ref> * In 1996, [[Reba McEntire]] portrayed Oakley in ''[[Buffalo Girls]]'' alongside [[Anjelica Huston]], [[Melanie Griffith]] and [[Tom Wopat]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0111903/?ref_=nv_sr_2|title=Buffalo Girls (TV Mini-Series)|last=|first=|date=|website=IMDb|access-date=}}</ref> * In 2004, [[Elizabeth Berridge (actress)|Elizabeth Berridge]] played Oakley in the [[Touchstone Pictures]] film ''[[Hidalgo (film)|Hidalgo]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0317648/?ref_=nv_sr_2|title=Hidalgo (2004)|last=|first=|date=|website=IMDb|access-date=}}</ref> * In 2009, [[Sarah Strange]] played Oakley in the episode "Mild Mild West" of the Canadian crime drama television show, ''[[Murdoch Mysteries]]''.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1379506/|title="Murdoch Mysteries" Mild Mild West (TV Episode 2009)|last=|first=|date=|website=IMDb|access-date=}}</ref> * In 2016, Oakley was played by [[Alyssa Edwards]] during the "HERstory of the World" episode of ''[[RuPaul's Drag Race: All Stars|RuPaul's Drag Race All Stars]]''.<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://tv.avclub.com/drag-race-all-stars-reaches-its-full-potential-when-the-1798188723 |title=Drag Race All Stars reaches its full potential when the queens get personal |last=Sava |first=Oliver |date=2016-09-08 |website=TV Club |language=en-US |access-date=2018-04-22|df=mdy-all}}</ref> * One of the main characters of the videogame ''[[Wild Guns]]'' is based on Oakley, including costume and attire.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.nintendoworldreport.com/recommendations/24552/a-cowboy-walks-into-a-tent |title=A Cowboy Walks Into a Tent - Recommendations |last=Hernandez |first=Pedro |date=2010-12-16 |website=Nintendo World Report |access-date=2018-04-22|df=mdy-all}}</ref>
==Influence== Oakley's worldwide stardom as a sharpshooter enabled her to earn more money than most of the other performers in the Buffalo Bill show.<ref name="AmExAOBio"/> She did not forget her roots after gaining financial and economic power. She and Butler together often donated to charitable organizations for orphans.<ref name="AmExAOBio"/> Beyond her monetary influence, she proved to be a great influence on women.
Oakley urged that women serve in war, though President McKinley rejected her offer of woman sharpshooters for service in the [[Spanish–American War]].<ref name="archives.gov"/> Beyond this offer to the president, Oakley believed that women should learn to use a gun for the empowering image that it gave.<ref name="bestshot">{{cite journal|last=Isenberg|first=Nancy|date=February 2008|title=Review: ''Her Best Shot: Women and Guns in America'' by Laura Browder|journal=The Journal of Southern History|publisher=[[Southern Historical Association]]|volume=74|issue=1|pages=175–176|jstor=27650088}}<!--|access-date=December 2, 2014 --></ref> Laura Browder discusses how Oakley's stardom gave hope to women and youth in ''Her Best Shot: Women and Guns In America''. Oakley pressed for women to be independent and educated.<ref name=bestshot/> She was a key influence in the creation of the image of the American cowgirl. Through this image, she provided substantial evidence that women are as capable as men when offered the opportunity to prove themselves.<ref>{{cite journal|date=June 1998|title=Doctoral Dissertations in American Studies, 1996–1997|journal=[[American Quarterly]]|publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press|volume=50|issue=2|pages=447–469|doi=10.1353/aq.1998.0019|jstor=30041628}}<!--|access-date=December 2, 2014 --></ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2017}}
'''Anton Salonen''' ({{lang-ru|Антон Салонен}}, born 3 October 2003)<ref name="Interfax">{{Cite news | script-title=ru:Финский поворот | author = Vladimir Shishlin | agency = [[Interfax]] | url = http://www.interfax.ru/society/txt.asp?id=81186 | date = 22 May 2009 | language = Russian }}</ref> is a child with Russian-Finnish [[dual citizenship]] involved in an international [[child custody]] dispute between his parents.<ref name="noottiuhka">{{Cite journal | title = NOOTTIUHKA! - Anton pojan pitkä piina |journal=[[Ilta-Sanomat]] | date = 16 May 2009 | issue = 112 | pages=2–3}}</ref><ref name="Times">{{Cite journal |page= TOP STORIES | title = Diplomatic Spat Over Boy Taken To Finland |author=Irina Titova |journal=[[St. Petersburg Times]] | issue = 1475 | volume = 37 |url=http://www.sptimesrussia.com/index.php?action_id=2&story_id=29029 |date=19 May 2009 |accessdate=2009-05-19}}</ref> The Finnish-born child was first [[Child abduction|abducted]] by his [[Estonian Russians|Estonian Russian]] mother in 2008 and taken to Russia. In turn the boy was abducted by his father in 2009 and smuggled back to Finland with the help of Finnish diplomats stationed at the [[Finnish consulate in Saint Petersburg]].<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Konsulaatin työntekijä auttoi Anton-pojan salakuljetuksessa |url=http://www.aamulehti.fi/uutiset/kotimaa/konsulaatin-tyontekija-auttoi-anton-pojan-salakuljetuksessa/143207 |author=Tapio Pessi |journal=[[Aamulehti]] |date=15 May 2009 |accessdate=2009-05-16 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090517061237/http://www.aamulehti.fi/uutiset/kotimaa/konsulaatin-tyontekija-auttoi-anton-pojan-salakuljetuksessa/143207 |archivedate=17 May 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The incident has sparked a diplomatic row between [[Finland]] and [[Russia]].<ref name="russiatoday">{{Cite web | title = Russia lashes out at Finland over kidnapping | url = http://www.russiatoday.com/Top_News/2009-05-15/Russia_lashes_out_at_Finland_over_kidnapping.html | publisher = [[Russia Today]] | format = video | date = 15 May 2009 | accessdate = 2009-05-16 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090516054550/http://www.russiatoday.com/Top_News/2009-05-15/Russia_lashes_out_at_Finland_over_kidnapping.html | archivedate = 16 May 2009 | deadurl = yes | df = dmy-all }}</ref><ref name="eTaiwan">{{Cite news |title=Boy's fate sparks Russia-Finland dispute |url=http://www.etaiwannews.com/etn/news_content.php?id=950553&lang=eng_news |publisher=eTaiwan News |date=15 May 2009 |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=2009-05-18}}</ref><ref name="Sanomat">{{Cite journal |date=18 May 2009 |title=Child abduction case prompts ministerial-level altercation between Finland and Russia |url=http://www.hs.fi/english/article/Child+abduction+case+prompts+ministerial-level+altercation+between+Finland+and+Russia/1135246055489 |journal=Helsingin Sanomat, International Edition |accessdate=2009-05-19 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090521133657/http://www.hs.fi/english/article/Child%2Babduction%2Bcase%2Bprompts%2Bministerial-level%2Baltercation%2Bbetween%2BFinland%2Band%2BRussia/1135246055489 |archivedate=21 May 2009 |deadurl=no }}</ref> The Finnish diplomat who helped to abduct the child was dismissed from the Finnish Consulate and Russia has declared him [[persona non grata]].<ref name="rian_nongrata"/>
== Background == Anton's Finnish father and Russian Estonian mother met in [[Tallinn]], [[Estonia]] in 1994 and married in 1997. The pair filed for legal divorce in 2002, which came into effect on 13 January 2003, but they continued to live together until 2005. Anton was born out of wedlock on 3 October 2003.<ref name="Interfax" /><ref name="alueviesti">{{Cite journal | title = Paavo Salosen taistelu kestänyt jo vuoden | author = | url = http://www.alueviesti.fi/alueviesti_ajankohtaiset.php?tiedote_id=531 | journal = Alueviesti | date = | accessdate = 2009-05-16 | language = Finnish}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> At birth Anton was legally entitled to Russian citizenship, but the citizenship was never registered.<ref name="Interfax" /> He was registered as a Finnish citizen after the Finnish father's paternity had been established. His mother gained Finnish citizenship via naturalisation after the birth.<ref>{{Cite web|title=Rimma Salosen vastine Paavo Salosen hyökkäyksiin |url=http://www.suomi.ru/forum/showthread.php?t=49295&page=25&pp=30 |date=6 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080616012623/http://www.suomi.ru/forum/showthread.php?t=49295 |archivedate=2008-06-16}}</ref> After the divorce the parents had [[joint custody]].
From a previous marriage of his mother, Anton has an older, 19-year-old brother, whom she left in Finland.<ref name="rian-en-1">{{Cite web | title = Russia lashes out at Finland over kidnapping |url=http://en.rian.ru/russia/20090803/155713900.html |publisher=[[RIA Novosti]] |date=8 August 2009 |accessdate=2009-08-04}}</ref>
=== Abduction by mother to Russia === Anton's mother left Finland with Anton without the consent of the father on 5 March 2008.<ref name="Interfax" /><ref>{{Cite journal | title = Missä on Anton? | author = Timo Myllyniemi | url = http://www.iltasanomat.fi/uutiset/kotimaa/uutinen.asp?id=1514179 | journal = [[Ilta Sanomat]] | date = 4 April 2008 | accessdate = 2009-05-17 | language = Finnish| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090519212621/http://www.iltasanomat.fi/uutiset/kotimaa/uutinen.asp?id=1514179| archivedate= 19 May 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The [[Embassy of Russia in Helsinki|Russian Embassy in Finland]] assisted the mother with the Russian [[Visa (document)|visa]] application.<ref name="us2">{{Cite journal|title=Anton-pojan draamasta löytyi outoja yksityiskohtia |url=http://www.uusisuomi.fi/kotimaa/60355-anton-pojan-draamasta-loytyi-outoja-yksityiskohtia |journal=[[Uusi Suomi]] |date=17 May 2009 |accessdate=2009-05-20 |language=Finnish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716132432/http://www.uusisuomi.fi/kotimaa/60355-anton-pojan-draamasta-loytyi-outoja-yksityiskohtia |archivedate=2011-07-16 |df= }}</ref> The signature of the father is presumed to have been forged on the application.<ref name="us3">{{Cite journal | title = Jarmo Koponen: Anton Salonen | url = http://www.uusisuomi.fi/nakokulmat/jarmokoponen/anton-salonen | journal = [[Uusi Suomi]] | date = 17 May 2009 | accessdate = 2009-05-23 | language = Finnish | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090519221416/http://www.uusisuomi.fi/nakokulmat/jarmokoponen/anton-salonen | archivedate = 19 May 2009 | deadurl = yes | df = dmy-all }}</ref>
The 65-year-old father blames a religious organization near the [[Russian Orthodox Church]] in Finland for the abduction,<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Kaapatun pojan isä uskoo jälkien johtavan Vammalan Stormiin |author=Maija Latva |url=http://jps-dev.net/alueviesti/pdf_files/200804081035020.2.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110819034313/http://jps-dev.net/alueviesti/pdf_files/200804081035020.2.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=19 August 2011 |journal=Alueviesti |date=9 April 2008 |accessdate=2009-05-16 |pages=5–6 |language=Finnish }}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|title=Pikku-Anton pääsee kotiin Suomeen |url=http://www.satakunnankansa.fi/cs/Satellite?c=AMArticle_C&childpagename=SKA_newssite%2FAMLayout&cid=1194608106873&p=1192553427666&pagename=SKAWrapper |author=Tapio Pessi |journal=Satakunnan Kansa |date=20 November 2008 |accessdate=2009-05-16 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717003940/http://www.satakunnankansa.fi/cs/Satellite?c=AMArticle_C&childpagename=SKA_newssite%2FAMLayout&cid=1194608106873&p=1192553427666&pagename=SKAWrapper |archivedate=2011-07-17 |df= }}</ref> calling the Memorial Society of [[Seraphim of Sarov|Saint Seraphim of Sarov]] ({{lang-fi|Serafim Sarovilaisen Muistoyhdistys}})<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uskonnot.fi/yhteisot/view?orgId=933|title=Pyhittäjäisä Serafim Sarovilaisen Muistoyhdistys ry|website=www.uskonnot.fi|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref> a [[sect]]. The lower court in [[Tampere]] ordered that the mother be detained on suspicion of [[child abduction]]. The order is only effective inside the [[European Union]].<ref name="iltalehti">{{Cite journal | title = Anton unohti suomen kielen | url = http://www.iltalehti.fi/uutiset/200807237990209_uu.shtml | journal = [[Iltalehti]] | date = 23 July 2008 | accessdate = 2009-05-16 | language = Finnish}}</ref> Russia is not a signatory of the [[Hague Convention on the Civil Aspects of International Child Abduction]]. The court also gave sole custody of the child to the father.<ref name="iltalehti" /> In Russia Anton was granted Russian citizenship based on information provided by the mother. According to Uusi Suomi this sort of citizenship is normally granted in months, not in days.<ref name="us2" />
After locating the child and mother in [[Balakhna]] near [[Nizhny Novgorod]] the father initiated legal proceedings in Russia to regain custody and revoke the Russian citizenship.<ref name="Sanomat"/> On 20 November 2008, the Balakhna City Court revoked Anton's Russian citizenship because his mother had presented false information for registration of citizenship. On 17 March 2009, the judicial board on civil cases of the Nizhny Novgorod regional court upheld the decision.<ref name="Interfax" /><ref>{{Cite news | title = Похищенный в Балахне 5-летний мальчик не имеет российского гражданства – решение суда | url = http://nta-nn.ru/news/item/?ID=153000 | publisher = NTA Privolzhie | date = 18 May 2009 | accessdate = 2009-05-19}}</ref> After the decision, the father came to Russia to take Anton back to Finland.
=== Abduction by father ===
Russian online newspaper Grani.ru claimed that in April 2009 Anton was forcibly taken from his mother by his father outside her home on Ryazanova Street.<ref>{{Cite web | title = СКП расследует дело о похищении Антона Салонена | url = http://www.sj3.ru/cgi-bin/iframe/grani?820715 | work = [[grani.ru]] | date = 15 May 2009 | accessdate = 2009-05-17 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090417181414/http://www.sj3.ru/cgi-bin/iframe/grani?820715 | archivedate = 17 April 2009 | deadurl = yes | df = dmy-all }}</ref> The press service of Russia's Investigation Committee alleges that on 12 April 2009, the father, acting in conspiracy with persons unknown, attacked the mother and retrieved Anton.<ref>{{Cite news | title = ФИНН, ПОХИТИВШИЙ СЫНА АНТОНА, МОЖЕТ ПОПАСТЬ В РОССИЙСКУЮ ТЮРЬМУ | date=16 May 2009 | url = http://www.regions.ru/news/contries/2215100/ | publisher = regions.ru | accessdate = 2009-05-19}}</ref> After allegedly being prevented from leaving Russia, the father and son took refuge at a vacant apartment of the [[List of diplomatic missions of Finland|Finnish Consulate-General]] in [[Saint Petersburg]].
The Russian authorities allegedly ignored the earlier Russian court decision and Anton's Russian citizenship was expeditiously re-instated on May 7.<ref name="alueviesti" /> One day later, on 8 May, Anton was smuggled to Finland in the closed [[diplomatic bag|trunk]] of a diplomatic car by the legal consul at the Saint Petersburg consulate, [[Simo Pietiläinen]].

|deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> causing a diplomatic incident.<ref name="russiatoday" /><ref name="eTaiwan" /> Russian foreign minister [[Sergey Lavrov]] called his Finnish counterpart [[Alexander the laws of the host country.<ref name="RIA1" /> The formal complaint was followed by a formal [[diplomatic note]] on May 20.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Venäjä jätti Suomelle nootin Anton Salosen salakuljetuksesta |author=Jouni Mölsä |url=http://www.hs.fi/politiikka/artikkeli/Ven%C3%A4j%C3%A4+j%C3%A4tti+Suomelle+nootin+Anton+Salosen+salakuljetuksesta/1135246120534 |journal=[[Helsingin |archivedate=21 May 2009 |deadurl=no }}</ref> Diplomat Pietiläinen, who helped take Anton out of Russia, was dismissed from the Finnish Consulate in St. Petersburg after the incident.<ref name="rian_nongrata">{{cite web|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20090608/155201873.html|title=Russia declares persona non grata Finnish boy-smuggling diplomat|date=2009-06-08|publisher=RIA The developments in St. Petersburg were closely followed by the Finnish government, including President [[Tarja Halonen]],<ref name="Halonen">{{Cite news | title = Tv-uutiset — Halonen: En tiennyt salakuljetuksesta etukäteen | url = http://areena.yle.fi/toista?id=2332172 | publisher = [[YLE]] | format = video | date = 19 May 2009 | accessdate = 2009-05-19 | language = Finnish }} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}</ref> who condemned the behaviour of Simo Pietiläinen<ref name="rian_nongrata"/> The actions of the Finnish diplomat involved were defended by Finnish Minister for Foreign Affairs [[Alexander Stubb]],<ref>{{Cite web | title = Stubb Defends Father and Consulate in Custody Battle | url = http://www.yle.fi/uutiset/news/2009/05/stubb_defends_father_and_consulate_in_custody_battle_740836.html | publisher = [[YLE]] | date = 15 May 2008 | accessdate = 2009-05-16 | language = English }}</ref> whilst Tarja Halonen has condemned them.<ref name="rian_nongrata"/> President Halonen,<ref name="Halonen" /> Prime Minister [[Matti Vanhanen]] and foreign minister Stubb all denied having prior knowledge of the smuggling plan or the involvement of Finnish diplomats in it.
== Conflict of law ==
There is a [[conflict of law]] between Finland and Russia. It is a criminal offense under Finish law for the Russian mother to take her child to Russia. It is a criminal offense under Russian law for the Finnish diplomat to take the same child from Russia back to Finland. This is why the Finnish diplomat was declared [[persona non grata]]. This is why the [[Russians|Russian]] mother faces [[parental abduction]] [[criminal charges]] in [[Finland]].
== Reactions ==
The incident has been widely covered in Finnish and [[Russian media]]<ref>{{Cite web | url = http://yle.fi/uutiset/ulkomaat/2009/05/suomeen_tuodun_anton-pojan_kohtalo_puhuttaa_venajalla_744040.html | title = Suomeen tuodun Anton-pojan kohtalo puhuttaa Venäjällä | publisher = [[YLE]] Uutiset | author = Liisa Lehmus | date = 18 May 2009 | accessdate = 2009-05-18 | language = Finnish | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090521123642/http://yle.fi/uutiset/ulkomaat/2009/05/suomeen_tuodun_anton-pojan_kohtalo_puhuttaa_venajalla_744040.html| archivedate= 21 May 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> in what some commentators have described as a [[Information warfare|media war]].<ref>{{Cite journal | title = Mediasotaa itärajan kahta puolta | author = Tuula Rantonen | journal = [[Karjalainen]] | page = editorial | url = http://www.karjalainen.fi/Karjalainen/Mielipiteet/mediasotaa_it%C3%A4rajan_kahta_puolta_5278889.html | date =19 May 2009 | accessdate = 2009-05-19 | language = Finnish | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090522191348/http://www.karjalainen.fi/Karjalainen/Mielipiteet/mediasotaa_it%C3%A4rajan_kahta_puolta_5278889.html| archivedate= 22 May 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The Russian media have speculated that the incident will have a negative effect on [[Finland–Russia relations]]. The case has also been compared to that of [[Eliza André]].<ref name="MosNews" /><ref>{{Cite news | title = Russia launches kidnapping probe against Finnish father | url = http://en.rian.ru/russia/20090515/155026679.html | agency = [[RIA Novosti]] | date = 15 May 2009 | accessdate = 2009-05-18 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090519000658/http://en.rian.ru/russia/20090515/155026679.html| archivedate= 19 May 2009 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The Investigation Committee of the Russian Prosecutor's office has launched criminal proceedings against the father on suspicion of "pre-meditated [[kidnapping]] of a person by an organized group" under article 126 of the [[Russian Criminal Code]].<ref name="Times" /><ref>{{Cite news | title = Finland investigates Anton Salonen case as border offence | url = http://newsroom.finland.fi/stt/showarticle.asp?intNWSAID=21726&group=General | agency = [[Suomen Tietotoimisto|STT]] | publisher = NewsRoom Finland | date = 18 May 2009 | accessdate = 2009-05-18 }}</ref>
== Trial of mother in Finland == Anton's mother returned to Finland on 1 August 2009. She was arrested at the airport in the [[Tampere]].<ref name="rian-en-1" /> A Finnish court considered the case of Anton's mother, and released her pending trial. However she was given a [[Persona non grata|travel ban]] for the next 60 days.<ref>http://www.hs.fi/kotimaa/artikkeli/Lapsikaappauksesta+ep%C3%A4ilty+Anton+Salosen+%C3%A4iti+matkustuskieltoon/1135248158522 Helsingin Sanomat: Lapsikaappauksesta epäilty Anton Salosen äiti matkustuskieltoon</ref> Through the Russian media, [[Johan Bäckman]] claimed that a Finnish police officer promised not to arrest Anton's mother, and furthermore the mother was allegedly arrested in [[Estonia]]'s capital [[Tallinn]].<ref name="rian-en-1" /> Bäckman was presented as one of the aides or lawyers<ref name="rian-en-1" /> of Rimma Salonen, while the trial lawyer is [[Heikki Lampela]] in Finland<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hs.fi/kotimaa/artikkeli/Johan+B%C3%A4ckman+Poliisi+ja+Antonin+is%C3%A4+tekiv%C3%A4t+ansan+Rimma+Saloselle/1135248128697|title=Helsingin Sanomat: Johan Bäckman: Poliisi ja Antonin isä tekivät ansan Rimma Saloselle|publisher=|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref> and [[Dmitry Glazov]] in Russia.{{Citation needed|date=August 2009}} Finnish media have reported some claims as a matter of inquiry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hs.fi/kotimaa/artikkeli/Rimma+Salosen+tapaus+kuohuttaa+Ven%C3%A4j%C3%A4ll%C3%A4/1135248189979|title=Helsingin Sanomat: Rimma Salosen tapaus kuohuttaa Venäjällä|publisher=|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref>
The incident has been top television news in Russia. The main villains have been Anton's Finnish father and the Finnish diplomat Simo Pietiläinen. Johan Bäckman has had a central role as commentator about the incident in Russia and Finland. His comments and speculation have been published as such, without checkup, in many Russian media, such as [[Ria Novosti]].<ref>[http://www.rian.ru/society/20090915/185147037.htmlРИА Новости: Финская прокуратура обвинила россиянку Салонен в похищении ребенка ]</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iltasanomat.fi/uutiset/kotimaa/uutinen.asp?id=1730495|title=Uutiset - Ilta-Sanomat|website=Ilta-Sanomat|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref><ref>Later, Rossiyanka interviewed the prosecutor, and corrected the false information: http://www.pravda.ru/news/society/18-09-2009/324434-sal-0</ref> Later Bäckman apologized his comments about the incident,<ref>[http://antonfree.blogspot.com/2009/10/johan-backmanin-julkinen-anteeksipyynto.html Johan Bäckman: Johan Bäckmanin julkinen anteeksipyyntö Paavo Saloselle] (in Finnish)</ref><ref>[http://www.hs.fi/kotimaa/artikkeli/Johan+B%C3%A4ckman+haluaa+sovitella+riidat+Paavo+Salosen+kanssa/1135250207917 Helsingin Sanomat: Johan Bäckman haluaa sovitella riidat Paavo Salosen kanssa] (in Finnish)</ref> but he has later recanted and is again arranging demonstrations against Paavo Salonen.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://antifasistit.blogspot.com/2012/05/vapauttakaa-anton-salonen-kansanvalinen.html|title=Vapauttakaa Anton Salonen. Kansanvälinen lehdistötilaisuus ja elokuvainfo Vaasassa 16.5.2012 kello 10. Mielenosoitus oikeustalolla klo 11.15.|publisher=|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref>
The Russian foreign ministry has made negative comments, and implied the negative effect of the incident to mutual relations between Russia and Finland.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.yle.fi/uutiset/ulkomaat/2009/08/anton-pojan_tapaus_nousi_ykkosuutiseksi_venajalla_906869.html|title=Anton-pojan tapaus nousi ykkösuutiseksi Venäjällä|website=Yle Uutiset|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref>
According to Finnish expert on Russia [[Ilmari Susiluoto]], the case of Anton is part of the Kremlin public relations campaign. The Finns have too positive an image in Russia, and this does not fit the Kremlin's idea of the "hostile outside world".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uusisuomi.fi/ulkomaat/67846-venajalla-nousi-suomi-kohu|title=Venäjällä nousi Suomi-kohu|publisher=|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref>
Rimma Salonen was given a one to five year [[suspended sentence]] for [[kidnapping]] and [[child abduction]] on 13 October 2009 in [[käräjäoikeus]] (lower court). She also had to pay 20,000 euros for emotional distress to her son and almost 4,800 euros to Paavo Salonen.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hs.fi/kotimaa/artikkeli/Rimma+Salonen+tuomittiin+ehdolliseen+vankeuteen/1135250005726|title=Helsingin Sanomat: Rimma Salonen tuomittiin ehdolliseen vankeuteen|publisher=|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref> The next year, [[hovioikeus]] (the Finnish appeals court) upheld Salonen's suspended prison sentence. However, the court did lower the damages awarded Anton Salonen to 10,000 euros. The court also ordered her to pay 7,500 euros in legal fees for Anton and Paavo Salonen.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://yle.fi/uutiset/news/2010/10/rimma_salonen_loses_appeal_2096393.html|title=Turku Appeal Court Upholds Sentence in Child Abduction Case|publisher=|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref>
== Aftermath == In May 2010, Russian Child Rights Ombudsman [[Pavel Astakhov]] accused the Finnish authorities of denying Anton the right to speak Russian. Astakhov also referred to statements of [[Johan Bäckman]] that Finnish authorities had also banned Anton from praying, being baptized, or wearing crosses.<ref>[http://www.rfdeti.ru/news/rubric-1.1/position-1400.html Office of the Children Rights Ombudsman for the President of the Russian Federation: П. Астахов намерен обратиться к Президенту Финляндии в связи с непрекращающимся]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} (in Russian) 18 May 2010</ref> A Russian newspaper reported these claims and referred Anton's mother and Bäckman to the [[Finnish Anti-Fascist Committee]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kp.ru/daily/24491/646716/|title=Дерусификация Антона Салонена идет полным ходом|first=Наталия ГРАЧЕВА | Сайт «Комсомольской|last=правды»|date=18 May 2010|publisher=|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mk.ru/social/article/2010/05/18/491559-v-finlyandii-zapretili-russkiy-yazyik.html|title=В Финляндии запретили русский язык|publisher=|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref>
In March 2011, Rimma Salonen announced she is a candidate for the [[Finnish parliamentary election, 2011|2011 Finnish parliamentary election]] for the [[Workers Party of Finland]]. She also represented the organization of [[Finnish Anti-Fascist Committee]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.iltasanomat.fi/vaalit2011/Huoltajuuskiistasta%20tuttu%20Rimma%20Salonen%20pyrkii%20eduskuntaan/art-1288373373617.html|title=Iltasanomat: Huoltajuuskiistasta tuttu Rimma Salonen pyrkii eduskuntaan|publisher=|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://antifasistit.blogspot.com/2011/03/jussi-parviainen-johan-backman-juha.html|title=Jussi Parviainen, Johan Bäckman, Juha Molari, Rimma Salonen ovat SAFKAn eduskuntavaaliehdokkaat!|publisher=|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref> Salonen got 16 votes.<ref>[http://192.49.229.35/E2011/e/tulos/ehdkutulos_helsinki.html Electoral district of Helsinki] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928082454/http://192.49.229.35/E2011/e/tulos/ehdkutulos_helsinki.html |date=2011-09-28 }} Official results of Finnish Justice Ministry</ref>
Russia joined the [[Hague Abduction Convention]] on 1 October 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hcch.net/index_en.php?act=events.details&year=2011&varevent=228|title=HCCH - The Russian Federation becomes the 86th Contracting State to the Hague Child Abduction Convention|first=e-Vision.nl, The|last=Netherlands|website=www.hcch.net|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref>
In April 2012 Rimma Salonen appealed to the Russian people and called for help because, according to her, Western authorities are stealing talented and unique Russian children to supplant Western children who are just robots and sex dolls.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://antifasistit.blogspot.com/2012/04/rimma-salonens-appeal-to-russian-people.html|title=Rimma Salonen's appeal to the Russian people|publisher=|accessdate=1 August 2017}}</ref>
In May 2013 [[Supreme Court of Finland]] decided not to give Rimma Salonen [[Certiorari|right to appeal]] for the ruling of Vaasa [[Hovrätt]]. This means Anton's father is his [[legal guardian]] as Vaasa Hovrätt ruled.<ref name="Mtv31707">{{Cite web|url=http://www.mtv3.fi/uutiset/kotimaa.shtml/2013/07/1781533/isa-voitti-anton-pojan-huoltajuuskiistan|title=Isä voitti Anton-pojan huoltajuuskiistan |publisher=Mtv3.fi|date=17 July 2013|accessdate=17 July 2013|language=fi}}</ref>

{{BLP sources|date=January 2009}} {{Chinese name|Bai}} [[File:Andrejs Klementjevs tiekas ar Ķīnas Nacionālās komitejas priekšsēdētāja vietnieku Bai Ličenu (8287670941).jpg|thumb|300px|Bai Lichen in December 2012]] '''Bai Lichen''' ({{zh|c=白立忱}}, [[Xiao'erjing]]: {{lang|zh-Arab|ﺑَﻰْ لِ چٌ }} ; born January 1941) is a retired Chinese politician of [[Hui people|Hui]] ethnicity, and the former chairman of [[Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region]] and the former president of [[All China Federation of Supply and Marketing Cooperatives]]. He was Vice Chairman of the [[Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference]] (CPPCC) between 1998 and 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.china.org.cn/china/CPPCC_anniversary/2009-09/17/content_18544115.htm|title=Bai Lichen|date=13 March 2008|work=[[China Internet Information Center]]|accessdate=27 December 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110123131420/http://china.org.cn/china/CPPCC_anniversary/2009-09/17/content_18544115.htm| archivedate= 23 January 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Born in [[Lingyuan]], [[Liaoning Province]], Bai graduated from department of agricultural engineering of Shenyang Institute of Agriculture in 1964, majoring in agricultural mechanization. He joined the [[Communist Party of China]] in April 1971. From 1964 to 1968, he was a technician in the Institute of Agricultural Mechanization in [[Yingkou]] of Liaoning. He was then sent to work in rural areas.
From 1972 to 1980, Bai was an official in the organization department of the [[Yingkou]] municipal party committee, and vice section chief of personnel bureau of Yingkou. In 1980, he was elevated to vice secretary and later, secretary of CPC committee in Suburbs District of Yingkou. In 1983, he became mayor and vice Party chief of Yingkou. In 1984, Bai was appointed as secretary of CPC [[Panjin]] municipal committee, and assistant to the Governor of Liaoning. In 1985, he was elevated to the Liaoning [[provincial party standing committee]], and vice governor of Liaoning. In 1986, Bai was transferred to Ningxia Hui Autonomous Region, and became [[Deputy Communist Party Secretary]] of Ningxia, and the acting chairman of Ningxia. He was confirmed as chairman of Ningxia in 1987, and served in this post for 10 years.
In 1997, Bai was appointed as the leader of the Party group of the All China Federation of Supply and Marketing Cooperatives. In 1998, he became the president of the Federation and was also elected as vice chairman of the [[Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference]].
Bai was a member of 13th, 14th, 15th, 16th and 17th Central Committees of the Communist Party of China. He has also been the vice chairman of 9th to 11th CPPCC.
