{{DISPLAYTITLE:Batman (''The Dark Knight Returns'')}} {{Multiple issues| {{refimprove|date=March 2008}} {{original research|date=May 2011}} }} {{Superherobox | image= Batman (Dark Knight Universe).jpg | caption = Cover of ''All Star Batman & Robin, The Boy
Wonder'' #1 (Oct. 2005). Art by Jim Lee | character_name = [[Batman]] | publisher = [[DC Comics]] ([[All-Star DC Comics|All-Star]] imprint) | debut = ''[[The Dark Knight Returns]]'' #1
([[1986 in comics#February|February 1986]]) | creators = [[Frank Miller (comics)|Frank Miller]] (concept)
(Based on [[Batman|the original character]], created by [[Bob Kane]] and [[Bill Finger]]) | alter_ego = Bruce Wayne | full_name = | species = | homeworld = | alliances=[[Batman Family]]
[[Justice League|Justice League of America]]
[[Gotham City Police Department]] | aliases = | supports= | powers = * [[Genius]]-level intellect * Peak human physical condition * Skilled [[martial arts|martial artist]] and hand-to-hand combatant * Expert detective * Utilizes high-tech equipment and weapons }} '''Batman''' ('''Bruce Wayne''') is a fictional [[superhero]] and an [[Alternative versions of Batman|alternative version]] of the [[DC Comics]] [[Batman|character of the same name]]. This version of Batman was created by [[Frank Miller (comics)|Frank Miller]] and first appeared in ''[[The Dark Knight Returns]]'' #1 ([[1986 in comics#February|February 1986]]). This satirical version of the character is regarded as an older, darker interpretation of the character who, after years of retirement, resumes his role as a vigilante and, eventually, a revolutionary [[freedom fighter]]. ==Publication history== {{Main article|Batman#The Dark Knight Returns and later}} In his introduction to ''The Dark Knight Returns'' #1, Frank Miller says that he got the idea for the character while going through a [[midlife crisis]], while on the verge of turning 30.''Batman: The Dark Knight Returns'' #1, February 1986 He later said that while he could tolerate the fact that his little brother was older than [[Spider-Man]], the fact that he himself was getting older than Batman "was something that needed to be stopped."[https://www.imdb.com/name/nm0588340/bio Frank Miller (II) - Biography] Although ''[[All Star Batman and Robin the Boy Wonder]]'' is printed under the [[All Star DC Comics]] [[imprint (trade name)|imprint]], it takes place in its own continuity outside of [[Grant Morrison]]'s ''[[All Star Superman]]'' [[canon (fiction)|canon]].[http://forum.newsarama.com/showthread.php?t=82819 Geoff Johns on All Star Batgirl] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071011204906/http://forum.newsarama.com/showthread.php?t=82819 |date=October 11, 2007 }} According to Miller, ''All Star Batman'' is the same version of his character set in the continuity of ''The Dark Knight Returns'' ''(DKR)'', ''[[Batman: Year One|Year One]]'' ''(YO)'', ''[[The Dark Knight Strikes Again]]'' ''(DKSA)'', and ''[[The Dark Knight III: The Master Race]]'' and ''Dark Knight Returns: The Last Crusade''. The series has an abstract depiction of its historical setting, as the satirical nature of the books often requires the aesthetic setting to shift with modern times with each new title; ''The Dark Knight Returns'' retained its 1980s themes due to its commentary on [[Ronald Reagan|Reagan]]-era politics, while the sequel more closely resembled [[George Bush, Jr.|Bush]]-era America and ''All Star Batman'' and ''The Master Race'' both resemble the nature of the contemporary "digital age". Out of all of the stories, ''Year One'' was the only one that also existed in the core DC continuity, until it was replaced by ''[[Batman: Zero Year]]''.[http://comics.ign.com/articles/685/685820p1.html ''Comics in Context #119: All Star Bats'' on IGN] At the end of the maxiseries ''[[52 (comics)|52]]'', it is revealed that a new DC [[Multiverse (DC Comics)|Multiverse]] of 52 different Earths now exists. The Dark Knight Universe ''(DKU)'' was formerly designated as "Earth-31", but it is not included amongst the current [[New 52]] [[DC Multiverse]] and another alternate Earth has taken its place. It is unclear whether the Dark Knight Universe still occurs within the canonical [[New 52]] DC multiverse, although the profiles of seven DC alternate Earths are still currently unknown according to the [[The Multiversity|''Multiversity'']] handbook. ''[[Spawn/Batman]]'', which has Batman team up with [[Todd McFarlane]]'s character [[Spawn (comics)|Spawn]], was released as a companion to ''The Dark Knight Returns'' and takes place in the same universe. == Characterization == This version of Batman's character has varied throughout the course of his publication history. In ''[[Batman: Year One]]'' and ''The Dark Knight Returns'', he is basically still the brooding, bitter vigilante from the mainstream comics, while in ''All Star Batman and Robin the Boy Wonder'' and ''The Dark Knight Strikes Again'', he has evolved into something of an [[antihero]]. In ''The Dark Knight Strikes Again'', his actions could at least be justified since he is fighting a high-stakes war against [[Lex Luthor]] and [[Brainiac (character)|Brainiac]]'s police-state regime, in which attempting to preserve life could be seen as a weakness. In ''All Star Batman and Robin the Boy Wonder'', however, he appears to brutalize criminals for the fun of it, and even goes as far as to berate and abuse the young [[Dick Grayson]] after kidnapping him after his parents died (though in this case, interior monologues show that he is in conflict with himself for these actions). At the end of ''The Dark Knight Strikes Again'', after Luthor and Brainiac have been defeated and the world now in the safe hands of Superman, Batman encounters Dick as the new "[[Joker (comics)|Joker]]" and kills him rather than try to rehabilitate him. == Fictional character biography == Much like the mainstream [[New Earth (DC Comics)|New Earth]]/[[Post-Crisis]] Batman, Miller's [[Batman]] begins his journey after his parents are murdered by [[Joe Chill]]. (However, in ''Dark Knight Returns'', it is hinted that he never found out who murdered his parents.) He travels the world in search of a means to fight crime, which include various forms of [[martial arts]] and forensic skills. After returning to [[Gotham City]] in his early twenties, Bruce takes up the mantle of the Batman. In his first few months, he exposes [[police corruption]] in the [[Gotham City Police Department]], unsettles the empire of crime lord [[Carmine Falcone]], and gains an ally in Lieutenant [[James Gordon (comics)|James Gordon]]. At some unspecified point, shortly after the events of ''Year One'', he stops [[The Joker (comics)|The Joker]] from poisoning Gotham's water supply.[[Batman: Year One]] Also around this time, he uses the Gotham sewers as his first [[Batcave]] to prove to himself that he doesn't need his wealth, and learns [[Catwoman]]'s identity. In the second year of his career, Batman takes on a protégé in young acrobat [[Dick Grayson]], whose parents are killed by a hitman upon The Joker's orders. Batman accepts Dick into his inner circle, and he debuts as [[Robin (comics)|Robin]]. It is during this time that he meets [[Justice League of America]] (JLA) members [[Superman]] and [[Hal Jordan]], to whom he shows complete disrespect. During this time, Bruce Wayne grows to love being Batman and constantly refers to himself as ''the Goddamn Batman''. His own inexperience makes him reckless and ruthless towards criminals, however, and he treats Dick with nothing short of abuse and contempt, forcing him to live uncomfortably in the Batcave and chastising [[Alfred Pennyworth]] for showing him kindness.[[All Star Batman and Robin the Boy Wonder]] Fifteen years prior to the events of ''DKR'', Batman fires Dick (the reason is unknown, though Batman states it was for "cowardice and incompetence") and replaces him with [[Jason Todd]]. Some time later, Bruce is involved in riots, during which he modifies the [[Batmobile]] to its tank-like structure. Batman later becomes a member of the JLA and seems to develops a strong friendship with [[Hal Jordan]] ([[Green Lantern]]), similar to his friendship with Superman in the Mainstream DC Universe, twelve years before ''DKR''. Batman apprehends [[Two-Face]] one last time before his retirement. Two-Face's last crime is the kidnapping of [[conjoined twins|Siamese twins]], and the JLA is pressured into disbanding by [[political correctness]] groups. While most members of the JLA retire, Superman goes to work for the government, and Batman continues to fight crime in Gotham. Batman's best friend in the superhero community, Hal Jordan, retires to space, though Batman begs him to stay. [[Arkham Asylum]] for the Criminally Insane becomes Arkham Home for the Emotionally Troubled, due to the wave of political correctness. Batman and Robin investigate a strange blackmail case involving [[Poison Ivy (comics)|Poison Ivy]], during which Bruce becomes injured and Jason becomes increasingly violent and unpredictable. The Joker escapes Arkham soon after. Jason, upset that Batman is not pursuing the Joker after he escaped, goes to where the Joker is staying and tries to break in. He is killed by the Joker's henchmen, who were waiting outside the door before he entered. Ten years before ''DKR'', Batman retires over the burden of Jason's death. According to Superman, the other superheroes "almost threw a party." The Joker enters a catatonic state for about ten years due to Batman's disappearance. Seven years before ''DKR'', Bruce crosses paths with Dick again, but it ends badly and they part ways on bad terms. Over the next decade, Bruce takes to drinking heavily and engaging in near-[[suicide|suicidal]] risk-taking. Despite maintaining his image as a playboy, he invests a considerable amount in the rehabilitation of Harvey Dent, the former [[Two-Face]]. Following an "anniversary" of Batman's last crusade with Jim Gordon, a 55-year-old Bruce is almost mugged by a group of street hoods. He defends himself, realizing that he cannot ignore the rising wave of crime. A new teenage gang called "The Mutants" begins to terrorize the police and citizens of Gotham. Bruce begins suffering [[night terrors]] and [[somnabulism|sleepwalking]] which ends in his waking in the Batcave. After watching ''[[The Mark of Zorro (1920 film)|The Mark of Zorro]]'' and reliving the murders of his parents (who had taken him to see the film on the night they were killed), he dons the cape and cowl once more. He manages to save Gotham from Two-Face and the Mutant gang, and takes on a new sidekick — [[Carrie Kelley]], the new Robin. When the Joker reappears and kills hundreds of people, Batman fights him one last time, but the Joker kills himself and Batman is framed for his murder. Superman is sent by the government to stop Batman's increasingly violent style of vigilantism. Batman confronts the Man of Steel with a variety of weapons, including several missiles and a sonic gun. Batman fights Superman to what appears to be his own death, but not before beating Superman. It is later revealed that he was induced to catatonia but revived to lead an underground subversive movement alongside Carrie, [[Green Arrow]] and the Mutants (renamed as the Sons of Batman).[[The Dark Knight Returns]] In the years after going underground, Bruce Wayne and Carrie (now known as Catgirl) train an army of "Batboys" to save the world from a "[[police-state]]" [[dictatorship]] led by [[Lex Luthor]]. In a series of raids on government facilities, Batman's soldiers release from captivity other superheroes including: the [[Atom (Ray Palmer)|Atom]] (trapped for years in a [[petri dish]]), [[Flash (Barry Allen)|Flash]] (forced to run on a treadmill to provide America with free power), and [[Plastic Man]] (now insane and trapped in [[Arkham Asylum]]). [[Elongated Man]] is recruited from his job as a commercial spokesman and Green Arrow is working with Batman.[[The Dark Knight Strikes Again]] Luthor responds by sending a genetically-superpowered man who resembles the Joker to kill as many superheroes as possible. Batman, with help from his allies, manages to take Luthor down, and Luthor is killed by the son of [[Hawkman]], who had been killed earlier on by Luthor. As he returns home, Batman receives a communication from Carrie, who is being attacked by the new Joker. Batman rushes to her aid and recognises the man as Dick, who has been genetically manipulated to possess a powerful healing factor, but has been driven insane. Batman shows nothing but contempt for his former sidekick and plans his death the moment they face each other. Batman hurls himself and Dick into a miles-deep crevasse filled with lava and blows up the entire cave, igniting an underground volcano and destroying everything. Dick falls into the lava and is killed, but Batman is saved by Superman at the last moment and brought to Carrie in the Batmobile. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.comicbookresources.com/news/newsitem.cgi?id=233|Frank Miller on ''Dark Knight Strikes Again''] {{Batman}} {{Batman characters}} [[Category:DC Comics superheroes]] [[Category:Batman characters]] [[Category:Comics characters introduced in 1986]] [[Category:Characters created by Frank Miller]] [[Category:American comics adapted into films]] [[Category:DC Comics martial artists]] [[Category:Fictional people with eidetic memory]] [[Category:Fictional escapologists]] [[Category:Fictional orphans]] [[Category:Fictional socialites]] [[Category:Fictional vigilantes]] [[Category:Fictional aviators]] [[Category:Fictional forensic scientists]] [[Category:Fictional Jeet Kune Do practitioners]] [[Category:Fictional Shaolin kung fu practitioners]] [[Category:Fictional Muay Thai practitioners]] [[Category:Fictional Brazilian jiu-jitsu practitioners]] [[Category:Fictional Gōjū-ryū practitioners]] [[Category:Fictional shotokan practitioners]] [[Category:Fictional kyokushin kaikan practitioners]] [[Category:Fictional Ninjutsu practitioners]] [[Category:Fictional jujutsuka]] [[Category:Fictional judoka]] [[Category:Fictional karateka]] [[Category:Fictional aikidoka]] [[Category:Fictional Wing Chun practitioners]] [[Category:Fictional business executives]] [[Category:Fictional criminologists]] [[Category:Fictional detectives]] [[Category:Fictional inventors]]

{{about||the footballer|Bobby Clarke (footballer)|the rock drummer|Bobbie Clarke}} {{Infobox ice hockey player | halloffame = 1987 | image = Bob Clarke after his last ever game Jan 14, 2017.jpg | image_size = 230px | caption = Clarke after the 2017 Alumni game on January 14, 2017 | position = [[Centre (ice hockey)|Centre]] | shoots = Left | height_ft = 5 | height_in = 10 | weight_lb = 176 | played_for = [[Philadelphia Flyers]] | ntl_team = CAN | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1949|8|13}} | birth_place = [[Flin Flon, Manitoba|Flin Flon]], [[Manitoba]], Canada | draft = 17th overall | draft_year = 1969 | draft_team = [[Philadelphia Flyers]] | career_start = 1969 | career_end = 1984 }}
'''Robert Earle Clarke''' (born August 13, 1949), also known as '''Bob Clarke''' (since retirement as a player) and '''Bobby Clarke''' (while active as a player), is a [[Canadians|Canadian]] former professional [[ice hockey]] [[Centre (ice hockey)|centre]] who played his entire 15-year [[National Hockey League]] (NHL) career with the [[Philadelphia Flyers]] and is currently an executive with the team.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://flyers.nhl.com/club/page.htm?id=35749|title=Bio - Clarke - Philadelphia Flyers - Team |publisher=Philadelphia Flyers |accessdate=October 9, 2013}}</ref> Clarke is widely acknowledged as being one of the greatest hockey players and [[Captain (ice hockey)|captains]] of all time.<ref>{{cite web|last=Pelletier |first=Joe |url=http://broadstreetbullies.blogspot.com/2006/05/bobby-clarke.html |title=Bobby Clarke |publisher=Greatest Hockey Legends.com |accessdate=June 15, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Hoffman |first=Patrick |url=http://www.sportsnet.ca/hockey/nhl/top-10-captains-in-nhl-history/ |title=Top 10 captains in NHL history |publisher=[[Sportsnet]] |accessdate=May 14, 2017}}</ref> He was captain of the Flyers from 1973 to 1979, winning the [[Stanley Cup]] with them in both [[1974 Stanley Cup Finals|1974]] and [[1975 Stanley Cup Finals|1975]]. He was again captain of the Flyers from 1982 to 1984 before retiring. A 3-time [[Hart Memorial Trophy|Hart Trophy]] winner and 1987 [[Hockey Hall of Fame]] inductee, Clarke was rated number 24 on [[The Hockey News]]' list of ''[[List of 100 greatest hockey players by The Hockey News|The Top 100 NHL Players of All-Time]]'' in 1998.<ref>Steve Dryden, [https://www.amazon.com/dp/0771041756/ The Top 100 NHL Players of All-Time], 1998</ref> In 2017 Clarke was named one of the '[[100 Greatest NHL Players]]' in history.<ref>{{cite web|title=100 Greatest NHL Players|url=https://www.nhl.com/fans/nhl-centennial/100-greatest-nhl-players|publisher=National Hockey League|accessdate=January 27, 2017|date=January 27, 2017}}</ref>
Clarke had three 100-point seasons, twice leading the league in [[Assist (ice hockey)|assists]],<ref name="BSBblogspot">{{Cite web|url=http://broadstreetbullies.blogspot.com/2006/05/bobby-clarke.html|title=Philadelphia Flyers Legends: Bobby Clarke|date=May 2006|accessdate=2007-07-08|publisher=Greatest Hockey Legends.com|author=Joe Pelletier}}</ref> and played in eight [[NHL All-Star Game]]s. He also won the [[Frank J. Selke Trophy]] in [[1982–83 NHL season|1983]], as the league's best defensive forward.
Upon retiring at the end of the [[1983–84 NHL season|1983–84]] season with 358 goals and 852 assists for a total of 1,210 points in 1,144 career games, he immediately became general manager of the Flyers. He spent 19 of the following 23 seasons as a general manager of the Flyers, also briefly serving as general manager of the [[Minnesota North Stars]] and [[Florida Panthers]], and reached the Stanley Cup Finals three times with the Flyers and once with Minnesota. His time as an NHL general manager had its share of controversy, perhaps none greater than the rift between him and star player [[Eric Lindros]] during the late 1990s and early 2000s. He resigned from the general manager position less than a month into the [[2006–07 NHL season|2006–07]] season and is currently the Flyers' senior vice president.<ref name="SrVP">{{cite web|url=http://flyers.nhl.com/club/page.htm?id=35749|title=Bio - Clarke - Philadelphia Flyers - Team|publisher=philadelphiaflyers.com|accessdate=2011-05-08}}</ref>
The image of Clarke, with a toothless grin, embracing the Stanley Cup and winking following the Flyers' victory in the [[1975 Stanley Cup Finals]] is considered one of the most iconic and famous photos in the history of the sport of hockey.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.greatesthockeylegends.com/2008/08/greatest-photos-in-hockey-history-18.html|title=Bobby Clarke's Toothless Grin|accessdate=March 9, 2017}}</ref>
==Early life== [[Image:Clarke bombers.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Bobby Clarke's Bombers jersey on display at the [[2007 Memorial Cup]] in [[Vancouver]].]] Born in the small northern Manitoban mining town of Flin Flon,<ref name="Russia"/> Clarke began playing organized hockey when he was eight years old.<ref name="HonouredPlayer">{{Cite web|url=http://www.legendsofhockey.net/LegendsOfHockey/jsp/LegendsMember.jsp?mem=P198701&type=Player&page=bio&list=ByName#photo|title=The Legends - Honoured Player - Bobby Clarke - Biography|accessdate=2007-07-08|work=''LegendsofHockey.net''|publisher=Hockey Hall of Fame}}</ref> Around the time he was 12 or 13 years old, he learned he had [[Diabetes mellitus type 1|type 1 diabetes]].<ref name="Spotlight">{{Cite web|url=http://www.legendsofhockey.net/html/spot_oneononep198701.htm|title=Spotlight - One on One with Bobby Clarke|date=2003-05-02|accessdate=2007-07-08|author=Kevin Shea|work=''LegendsofHockey.net''|publisher=Hockey Hall of Fame|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929125237/http://www.legendsofhockey.net/html/spot_oneononep198701.htm|archive-date=2007-09-29|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Even though he progressed into a highly touted prospect playing for the [[Flin Flon Bombers]], leading the league in which the Bombers played in scoring in each of his last three years of junior hockey, NHL teams feared Clarke would never be able to play in the NHL because of his diabetes.<ref name="Russia">{{Cite web|url=http://english.portal.sport-express.ru/articles/9_68/|title=SPORT EXPRESS - BOBBY CLARKE: "I WAS NO FIGHTER..."|accessdate=August 9, 2012|work=Sports Express Daily|date=July 24, 2006|author=Slava Malamud|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140201201037/http://english.portal.sport-express.ru/articles/9_68/|archivedate=February 1, 2014|df=}}</ref> Bombers coach [[Pat Ginnell]] took Clarke to the [[Mayo Clinic]] in [[Minnesota]] following the 1967–68 season and the doctors concluded that as long as he took care of himself he could play professionally.<ref name="HonouredPlayer"/> Ginnell asked the doctors to write that statement down and when NHL scouts came to watch the Bombers play during the 1968–69 season, Ginnell showed them the doctor's verdict.<ref name="HonouredPlayer"/>
Even with such assurances Clarke fell to the second round of the [[1969 NHL Amateur Draft]] and was finally selected by the [[Philadelphia Flyers]] 17th overall. After [[Gerry Melnyk]], a scout and administrative assistant with the Flyers, tried to convince general manager [[Bud Poile]] to draft Clarke with their first-round pick and failed<ref name="FlyersHistoryHoF">{{Cite web|url=http://www.flyershistory.net/cgi-bin/hofprof.cgi?002|title=Flyers History - Hall of Fame Profile - Bobby Clarke|accessdate=2007-07-08|work=P. Anson|publisher=FlyersHistory.net}}</ref> — Poile drafted [[Bob Currier]] instead, a player who retired five years later and, ironically, never played a game in the NHL — Melnyk called a diabetes specialist in Philadelphia who said Clarke would be fine if he looked after his health.<ref name="Russia"/><ref name="Spotlight"/><ref name="FlyersHistoryHoF"/> Melnyk then successfully convinced Poile to draft Clarke when the Flyers second-round pick came around.<ref name="FlyersHistoryHoF"/> The [[Detroit Red Wings]] and [[Montreal Canadiens]] immediately offered the Flyers a deal for Clarke, Detroit offering two veteran players and Montreal offering a deal "Flyers management could hardly refuse."<ref name="HonouredPlayer"/> The Flyers refused both offers and made it clear Clarke was not for sale.<ref name="HonouredPlayer"/>
==NHL career== [[File:Bobby Clarke 1983.jpg|thumb|Clarke playing for [[Philadelphia Flyers]] in 1983]] Wearing #16, Clarke made his NHL debut on October 11, 1969, against the [[Minnesota North Stars]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flyershistory.net/cgi-bin/boxscore.cgi?19690004|title=Flyers History - Philadelphia Flyers Game Summary - 11-Oct-69|work=P. Anson|publisher=FlyersHistory.net|accessdate=2011-05-08}}</ref> He recorded his first point on October 22 against the [[Toronto Maple Leafs]], an assist on [[Lew Morrison]]'s 3rd period goal,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flyershistory.net/cgi-bin/boxscore.cgi?19690028|title=Flyers History - Philadelphia Flyers Game Summary - 22-Oct-69|work=P. Anson|publisher=FlyersHistory.net|accessdate=2011-05-08}}</ref> and he scored his first goal on October 30 against the [[New York Rangers]], beating Rangers goaltender [[Ed Giacomin]] 16:36 into the 3rd period.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flyershistory.net/cgi-bin/boxscore.cgi?19690047|title=Flyers History - Philadelphia Flyers Game Summary - 30-Oct-69|work=P. Anson|publisher=FlyersHistory.net|accessdate=2011-05-08}}</ref> Clarke played the entire 76-game schedule his rookie season and recorded 46 points (15 goals, 31 assists) while earning a trip to the [[NHL All-Star Game]].<ref name="FlyersHistoryStats">{{Cite web|url=http://www.flyershistory.net/cgi-bin/player.cgi?Bobby_Clarke|title=Individual Player Stats - Bobby Clarke|accessdate=2007-07-11|work=P. Anson|publisher=FlyersHistory.net}}</ref> He was also named NHL Rookie of the Year by [[Sporting News|The Sporting News]],<ref>{{cite web|last=Fish|first=Wayne|title=Clarke Named Most Courageous|url=https://newspaperarchive.com/the-daily-intelligencer/1980-01-29/page-31|work=The Daily Intelligencer|accessdate=20 March 2012|date=January 29, 1980}}</ref> and finished fourth in voting for the [[Calder Memorial Trophy]].<ref name="FlyersHistoryStats"/> Clarke led the Flyers in scoring during his sophomore season, [[1970–71 NHL season|1970–71]], with 27 goals and 36 assists for a total of 63 points in 77 games. His efforts helped the Flyers make the playoffs, but Clarke was held scoreless in his first playoff action and the Flyers lost in four games to the [[Chicago Blackhawks|Chicago Black Hawks]].<ref name="HonouredPlayer"/>
A [[tooth abscess]] was the cause of a slow start to the [[1971–72 NHL season|1971–72]] season;<ref name="FlyersHistoryHoF"/> 20 pounds underweight, Clarke only managed 5 goals and 11 assists 31 games into the season.<ref name="FlyersHistoryHoF"/> He rebounded over the final 47 games, scoring 30 goals and 35 assists<ref name="FlyersHistoryHoF"/> and bringing his totals to 35 goals and 46 assists. His dedication was rewarded when he became the first Flyer to win a major NHL award, the [[Bill Masterton Memorial Trophy]],<ref name="HonouredPlayer"/> and the Flyers re-signed him to a five-year contract worth $100,000 per season, a raise of $75,000 per season.<ref name="FlyersHistoryStats"/>
A few months following his strong play during the [[Summit Series]] for [[Canada men's national ice hockey team|Team Canada]], Clarke was named the Flyers' captain at age 23, the youngest to ever assume that role in NHL history at the time.<ref name="BSBblogspot"/> As leader of the brawling Broad Street Bullies, Clarke became the first player from an [[1967 NHL Expansion|expansion team]] to score more than 100 points in a season,<ref name="BSBblogspot"/> 104 points (37 goals, 67 assists) total. Facing the [[Minnesota North Stars]] in the first round, the Flyers and Clarke received a scare, as he was hit in the eye with a stick which broke his contact lens and was rushed to the hospital.<ref name="FlyersHistoryHoF"/> After removing parts of his broken contact from under the eye, Clarke returned to the lineup the next game despite having suffered a scratched cornea,<ref name="FlyersHistoryHoF"/> and the Flyers won their first playoff series. The Flyers lost to the [[Montreal Canadiens]] during the next round, but Clarke was later awarded the [[Hart Memorial Trophy]] as the league's MVP and the Lester B. Pearson Award as the league's most outstanding player as voted by the league's players.
Clarke's production fell to 87 points in 77 games during the [[1973–74 NHL season|1973–74]] regular season, but his leadership and [[Bernie Parent]]'s stellar goaltending led the Flyers to the second best record in the league and to the Stanley Cup Finals to play the team with the best record, the [[Boston Bruins]]. After losing Game 1, Clarke scored arguably the biggest goal of his career in overtime of Game 2, putting a rebound shot in over Bruins goaltender [[Gilles Gilbert]].<ref name="FlyersHistoryHoF"/> The Flyers won three of the next four games and became the first expansion team to win the [[Stanley Cup]].<ref name="BSBblogspot"/> Clarke played a key role in the Finals in countering Bruins' star players, winning 48 of the 66 face-offs against [[Phil Esposito]], and neutralizing [[Bobby Orr]] by chasing him down. The Stanley Cup winning goal in game six was scored after a fight between Clarke and Orr that sent both players to the penalty box.[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/hockey/nhl/features/si_stanley_cup/70s/#1974]
Clarke set the NHL record, at the time, for most assists by a centreman with 89<ref name="FlyersHistoryHoF"/> during the [[1974–75 NHL season|1974–75]] season on his way to a 116-point season. He finished second in the league in plus-minus rating with a plus 79, which illustrates his strong two-way play. The Flyers returned to the Stanley Cup Finals and defeated the [[Buffalo Sabres]] in six games, repeating as Stanley Cup champions. In addition to the second championship, Clarke was awarded the Hart Trophy for the second time, while being voted to the league's First All-Star Team.
[[1975–76 NHL season|1975–76]] was a record breaking season for Clarke. Playing on the LCB line with [[Reggie Leach]] and [[Bill Barber]], the trio set a record for most goals by a line with 141.<ref name="17thoverall">{{Cite web|url=http://www.hockeydraftcentral.com/1969/69017.html|title=1969 NHL Amateur Draft -- Bobby Clarke|accessdate=2007-07-08|publisher=HockeyDraftCentral.com}}</ref> He also tied his mark of the previous season with 89 assists and set a personal best and franchise record for most points in a single season with 119 (later broken by [[Mark Recchi]] in [[1992–93 NHL season|1992–93]]).<ref name="PHIseasonleaders">{{cite web|url=https://www.hockey-reference.com/teams/PHI/leaders_season.html|title=Philadelphia Flyers Season Leaders|work=Hockey-Reference.com|publisher=Sports Reference LLC|accessdate=2011-05-08}}</ref> He also led the league in plus-minus rating with a plus 83. The Flyers, without Parent and [[Rick MacLeish]],<ref name="FlyersHistoryHoF"/> made their third straight Finals appearance. However, Montreal coach [[Scotty Bowman]]'s strategy successful prevented Clarke's line from scoring and the Flyers were swept in four straight games.[http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/hockey/nhl/features/si_stanley_cup/70s/#1974] Clarke was awarded his third Hart Trophy and named to the NHL First All-Star team. Clarke's production would drop off over the next few seasons; in fact, his point total fell six seasons in a row. But the Flyers remained contenders, reaching the semifinals and losing to Boston in [[1976–77 NHL season|1976–77]] and [[1977–78 NHL season|1977–78]].
[[File:Bob_Clarke_2012.jpg|thumb|left|Clarke pictured during the Alumni game for the [[2012 NHL Winter Classic]] on December 31, 2011.]]After a quarterfinal loss to the Rangers in [[1978–79 NHL season|1978–79]], Clarke was named an assistant coach.<ref name="FlyersHistoryHoF"/> In order to become an assistant he had to give up the captaincy due to NHL rules,<ref name="FlyersHistoryHoF"/> so [[Mel Bridgman]] was named the 4th captain in Flyers history. His first season as a playing assistant coach, [[1979–80 NHL season|1979–80]], saw the Flyers go on an undefeated streak of 35 games, not only the longest in NHL history, but the longest in North American professional sports history.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flyershistory.com/streak.htm|title=Flyers History - The Streak - 35 Game Undefeated Streak|work=P. Anson|publisher=FlyersHistory.net|accessdate=2011-05-08}}</ref> The Flyers made it to the Stanley Cup Finals before losing to the [[New York Islanders]] in six games. During the playoffs, Clarke scored 8 goals and assisted on 12 others in 19 games, all 8 goals coming on the power play.<ref name="FlyersHistoryStats"/> Following the playoffs, Clarke was awarded the [[Lester Patrick Trophy]] along with Flyers owner [[Ed Snider]] and former Flyers coach [[Fred Shero]].
Clarke wore the number 16 throughout his entire NHL career except for two games during the {{NHL Year|1980}} season.<ref name="16stolen">{{Cite web|url=http://www.hockeybookreviews.com/2008/02/little-book-of-hockey-sweaters.html|title=Hockey Book Reviews.com: The Little Book Of Hockey Sweaters|accessdate=2011-02-02|date=2008-02-06|publisher=Joe Pelletier}}</ref> Prior to a road game on February 27, 1981,<ref name="36game1">{{cite web|url=http://www.flyershistory.net/cgi-bin/boxscore.cgi?19800064|title=Flyers History - Philadelphia Flyers Game Summary - 27-Feb-81|work=P. Anson|publisher=FlyersHistory.net|accessdate=2011-05-08}}</ref> Clarke's jersey was stolen.<ref name="16stolen"/> Clarke wore the only other jersey available, number 36,<ref name="16stolen"/> in the next two games.<ref name="36game1"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flyershistory.net/cgi-bin/boxscore.cgi?19800065|title=Flyers History - Philadelphia Flyers Game Summary - 28-Feb-81|work=P. Anson|publisher=FlyersHistory.net|accessdate=2011-05-08}}</ref> A month later, Clarke hit a personal milestone in memorable fashion. On March 19 during a game against the [[Boston Bruins]], a Reggie Leach slapshot struck Clarke.<ref name="FlyersHistoryHoF"/> After leaving the ice, he re-appeared moments later stitched up and with his jersey covered in blood.<ref name="FlyersHistoryHoF"/> 31 seconds into the third period Clarke beat Bruins goalie [[Marco Baron]] for his 19th goal of the season<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flyershistory.net/cgi-bin/boxscore.cgi?19800073|title=Flyers History - Philadelphia Flyers Game Summary - 19-Mar-81|work=P. Anson|publisher=FlyersHistory.net|accessdate=2011-05-08}}</ref> and his [[List of NHL players with 1000 points|1000th career point]].<ref name="FlyersHistoryHoF"/>
Despite his diabetes and hard-nosed play, Clarke proved to be remarkably durable. A broken foot suffered during the [[1981–82 NHL season|1981–82]] season<ref name="FlyersHistoryStats"/> limited him to 62 games, the only time in his career he played fewer than 70 games in a season. No longer an assistant coach, Clarke reassumed the captaincy from Bill Barber during {{NHL Year|1982}}. He skated in his [[List of NHL players with 1000 games played|1000th career game]] on October 23, 1982, against the [[Pittsburgh Penguins]]. Clarke had his best season since 1977–78, scoring 85 points in 80 games. He also won the [[Frank J. Selke Trophy]], given annually to the league's best defensive forward. After the Flyers were eliminated from the playoffs in the first round for the third straight season in {{NHL Year|1983}} and the general manager position opened up after [[Bob McCammon]] resigned,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/04/25/sports/sports-people-2-coaches-out.html|title=SPORTS PEOPLE; 2 Coaches Out|website=[[The New York Times]]|date=1984-04-25|accessdate=2011-05-15}}</ref> Clarke retired on May 15, 1984, to become the general manager of the Flyers.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1984/05/16/sports/sports-people-clarke-quits-playing.html|title=SPORTS PEOPLE; Clarke Quits Playing|website=[[The New York Times]]|date=1984-05-16|accessdate=2011-05-15}}</ref>
On January 14, 2017, Clarke played in the Flyers' 50th anniversary alumni game against the alumni of the Pittsburgh Penguins, where he combined with his longtime linemates, Bill Barber and Reggie Leach, which ended in a 3–3 tie before a sold out crowd of over 19,000 at the [[Wells Fargo Center (Philadelphia)|Wells Fargo Center]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Breen|first1=Matt|title=Alumni game marks a farewell of sorts for Flyers' Bob Clarke|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/sports/flyers/20170115_Alumni_game_marks_a_farewell_of_sorts_for_Flyers__Bob_Clarke.html|website=Philadelphia Daily News|accessdate=May 23, 2017|date=January 15, 2017}}</ref> Prior to the game Clarke announced that it would be his last alumni game.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Carchidi|first1=Sam|title=Clarke, Barber say alumni game will be their last|url=http://www.philly.com/philly/sports/flyers/20170112_Clarke__Barber_say_alumni_game_will_be_their_last.html|website=Philadelphia Daily News|accessdate=May 23, 2017|date=January 12, 2017}}</ref>
==International play== {{MedalTableTop|}} {{MedalCountry | {{ih|CAN}} }} {{MedalSport | [[Ice hockey]]}} {{MedalCompetition|[[Canada Cup]]}} {{MedalGold | [[1976 Canada Cup|1976 Canada]]|Ice Hockey}} {{MedalCompetition|[[Ice Hockey World Championships|World Championships]]}} {{MedalBronze | [[1982 World Ice Hockey Championships|1982 Finland]] |Ice Hockey}} {{MedalBottom}} {{See also|Canada men's national ice hockey team}}
Clarke played for Team Canada three times during his career. He played a major role in defeating the Soviet Union during the [[Summit Series]] in 1972, captained the Canadian team to gold at the [[1976 Canada Cup]], and won a bronze medal at the 1982 World Championships. In addition, he led the Flyers to the only [[1976 Flyers–Red Army game|outright victory]] over the Soviet Union's best team, Soviet Red Army, during the 1976 [[Super Series]], and took part in the [[1979 Challenge Cup (ice hockey)|1979 Challenge Cup]] with the NHL All-Stars. After his playing career, he served as one of Canada's four general managers during the [[1987 Canada Cup|1987]] and [[1991 Canada Cup]]s<ref name="17thoverall"/> and served as Canada's lone general manager during the [[1998 Winter Olympics]].
===Summit Series=== Coming off his third NHL season, Clarke was the last player Team Canada selected to play in the Summit Series.<ref name="1972SummitSeries">{{Cite web|url=http://www.1972summitseries.com/clarke.html|title=Clarke Did What He Had To Do|accessdate=2007-07-08|work=Joe Pelletier|publisher=1972summitseries.com}}</ref> His line with [[Ron Ellis]] and [[Paul Henderson]] turned out to be Canada's best during the series,<ref name="1972SummitSeries"/> Clarke tallying two goals and four assists in the eight game series won by Canada as well as being awarded Team Canada MVP in game one of the series.<ref name="1972SummitSeries"/> Clarke's play earned the respect of many during the series, Henderson saying, "The best thing that could have happened to Ronnie (Ellis) and me was to get this young kid making plays for us. He was terrific!"<ref name="1972SummitSeries"/> [[Wayne Cashman]] would add, "There were guys on Team Canada who took their game to new heights in that series. A perfect example would be Bobby Clarke."<ref name="1972SummitSeries"/> The Soviet team's assistant coach, [[Boris Kulagin]], thought Clarke was Canada's best player.<ref name="FlyersHistoryHoF"/> Clarke's strong play was largely attributed to the fact that, unlike many of the Canadian players, Clarke reported to training camp in top physical condition, as he had always followed a strict off-season training regimen. Though he earned much praise due to his play, he was also criticized for an incident during the sixth game which is often referred to as, "The Slash."<ref name="Slashof72">{{Cite web|url=http://proicehockey.about.com/library/blhenderson-clarke.htm|title=Classic Hockey Quotes - great hockey quotes past and present|accessdate=2007-07-08|publisher=About.com|year=2005}}</ref>
Clarke's line played against the line of the Soviets' top player, [[Valeri Kharlamov]], during the entire series.<ref name="Russia"/> After being on the receiving end of some stick work from Kharlamov while going for the puck,<ref name="Russia"/> Clarke caught up with Kharlamov and laid a two-handed slash across his ankle,<ref name="Russia"/> breaking it in the process.<ref name="Kharlamov">{{Cite web|url=http://www.chidlovski.com/personal/1972/yroster/ru17.htm|title=The Summit in 1972: Players Info - Valery Kharlamov|accessdate=2007-07-13|work=Arthur R. Chidlovski|publisher=chidlovski.com|year=2004}}</ref> Though Kharlamov finished the game, he missed the seventh game and was largely ineffective in the eighth.<ref name="Kharlamov"/> When asked about the slash years later, Clarke said, "If I hadn't learned to lay on a two-hander once in a while, I'd never have left Flin Flon."<ref name="1972SummitSeries"/> 30 years after the series, Henderson criticized Clarke, calling the slash, "the low point of the series."<ref name="Slashof72"/> Clarke responded saying that he thought it was "improper to criticize a teammate thirty years later," and that he did not "understand why he would bring it up now."<ref name="Slashof72"/> Henderson has since retracted his criticism.<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2002/09/19/clarke-henderson020919.html | publisher=[[CBC News]] | title=Paul Henderson sorry for criticizing Clarke slash | date=2002-10-07 |accessdate=2011-05-09}}</ref> Kharlamov, prior to his death in 1981, said he thought Clarke was tasked with "taking me out of the game."<ref name="Kharlamov"/> [[John Ferguson, Sr.]], an assistant coach with Team Canada in 1972, said, "I called Clarke over to the bench, looked over at Kharlamov and said, 'I think he needs a tap on the ankle.' I didn't think twice about it. It was Us versus Them. And Kharlamov was killing us. I mean, somebody had to do it. And I sure wasn't going to ask Henderson."<ref name="Slashof72"/> Clarke, however, does not recall Ferguson telling him this.<ref name="Russia"/>
===Nagano Olympics=== Named general manager of Team Canada on January 30, 1997,<ref name="17thoverall"/> Clarke was tasked with picking which NHLers would compete for Canada at the [[Ice hockey at the 1998 Winter Olympics|1998 Winter Olympics]] in Nagano, the first time NHLers would compete in the Olympics. A few of Clarke's choices were the source of some consternation, in particular omitting [[Mark Messier]] in favour of surprise selection [[Rob Zamuner]]<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.nytimes.com/1997/11/30/sports/hockey-gretzky-in-messier-out-as-canada-picks-team.html?pagewanted=all&src=pm | work=The New York Times | title=HOCKEY; Gretzky In, Messier Out As Canada Picks Team | first=Ed | last=Willes | date=1997-11-30 | accessdate=2011-05-09}}</ref> and choosing 24-year-old [[Eric Lindros]] as the team's captain over the likes of [[Wayne Gretzky]], [[Ray Bourque]], and [[Steve Yzerman]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/thestar/access/508439821.html?dids=508439821:508439821&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Feb+04%2C+1998&author=Roy+MacGregor&pub=The+Spectator&desc=All+eyes+on+Eric%3A+Is+24-year-old+Eric+Lindros+ready+to+carry+Canada's+hockey+hopes%3F&pqatl=google | title=All eyes on Eric: Is 24-year-old Eric Lindros ready to carry Canada's hockey hopes? | first=Roy | last=MacGregor | date=1998-02-04}}</ref> Ranked number one going into the tournament, Team Canada played strongly until being stymied by Czech goaltender [[Dominik Hašek]] in the semifinals, losing in a [[Shootout (ice hockey)|shootout]]. They then lost 3–2 to Finland in the bronze medal match.
==NHL management== Following his retirement, Clarke's first stint as Flyers general manager lasted six seasons and included two trips to the Stanley Cup Finals in [[1985 Stanley Cup Finals|1985]] and [[1987 Stanley Cup Finals|1987]]. After making the playoffs in each of his first five seasons in the front office, the Flyers fell off during the [[1989–90 NHL season|1989–90]] season and missed the playoffs, resulting in his firing by Flyers President [[Jay Snider]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/17/sports/sports-people-hockey-flyers-dismiss-clarke.html|title=SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY; Flyers Dismiss Clarke|website=[[The New York Times]]|date=1990-04-17|accessdate=2011-05-08}}</ref>
Clarke moved on to the [[Minnesota North Stars]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/06/09/sports/sports-people-hockey-north-stars-hire-clarke-as-general-manager.html|title=SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY; North Stars Hire Clarke As General Manager|website=[[The New York Times]]|date=1990-06-09|accessdate=2011-05-08}}</ref> and spent two seasons as the North Stars general manager, one of which saw a surprise run to the Finals in [[1991 Stanley Cup Finals|1991]].<ref name="17thoverall"/>
Leaving Minnesota, Clarke returned to Philadelphia to assume the role of Senior Vice President during the [[1992–93 NHL season|1992–93]] season, and served as a mentor for young phenom Eric Lindros during his first season.<ref name="17thoverall"/> Clarke moved on shortly after and took the general manager position with the expansion [[Florida Panthers]], a team which set the expansion team record for wins and points during a season in [[1993–94 NHL season|1993–94]]. He returned to the role of Flyers general manager prior to the [[1994–95 NHL season|1994–95]] season (Florida was compensated with cash and Philadelphia's second-round draft pick in the [[1994 NHL Entry Draft]]),<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1994/06/16/sports/sports-people-hockey-compensation-for-clarke.html|title=SPORTS PEOPLE: HOCKEY; Compensation for Clarke|website=[[The New York Times]]|date=1994-06-16|accessdate=2011-05-08}}</ref> and he rebuilt the team into a Cup contender. During his second tenure as general manager of the Flyers, the team made the playoffs 11 seasons in a row but reached the Finals once ([[1997 Stanley Cup Finals|1997]]). Following a poor start to the [[2006–07 NHL season|2006–07]] season, Clarke resigned citing a possible burnout and a lack of desire.<ref name="Resignation">{{Cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/nhl/news/story?id=2634817|title=Flyers GM Clarke resigns; coach Hitchcock fired|date=2006-10-24|accessdate=2007-07-26|publisher=ESPN}}</ref> Clarke returned to the franchise on December 4, 2006, and was named Senior Vice President.<ref name="SrVP"/>
===Controversy and criticism=== Clarke failed to win a Stanley Cup over the 22 seasons he was a general manager with Philadelphia, Minnesota, and Florida. During his 19 seasons as Flyers manager over two stints, the Flyers reached the Stanley Cup finals three times and amassed a regular season record of 714–443–199,<ref name="SrVP"/> but for one reason or another always came up short of a Cup title.<ref name="Doomed"/> Clarke's Flyers in 1985 and 1987 were considered underdogs to the powerhouse [[Edmonton Oilers]], as were his North Stars to the [[Pittsburgh Penguins]] in 1991. In his second tenure as Flyers manager, the team lost in the postseason, frequently to lower-seeded teams. While goaltending was a strength during his first tenure with two [[Vezina Trophy]] winners between the pipes ([[Pelle Lindbergh]] and [[Ron Hextall]]), only Hextall in 1995, a combination of Hextall and [[Garth Snow]] in 1997, [[Brian Boucher]] in [[1999–2000 NHL season|2000]], and [[Robert Esche]] in [[2003–04 NHL season|2004]] got the Flyers past the second round of the playoffs during his second stint. By contrast the [[New Jersey Devils]], their [[Atlantic Division (NHL)|Atlantic Division]] rivals, were stable in net with [[Martin Brodeur]] and beat the Flyers in the Conference Finals en route to Stanley Cups in 1995 and 2000.<ref name="Doomed">{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefourthperiod.com/columnists/wyshynski061023.html|title=The Legion of Doomed|date=2006-10-23|accessdate=2007-07-26|author=Greg Wyshynski|publisher=The Fourth Period|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070623085212/http://www.thefourthperiod.com/columnists/wyshynski061023.html|archive-date=2007-06-23|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
Clarke received his harshest criticism after first round playoff exits, including a string of four in five years from 1998 to 2002,<ref name="Resignation"/> and several coaching changes. After [[Terry Murray]] was fired following the team's sweep in the 1997 Stanley Cup Finals (some suggested that Murray lost the players' respect by describing the 6-1 loss in game three as a "choking situation"[http://www.hockeynut.com/9798/playoffs.html]), five more coaching changes were made in the next five years. [[Wayne Cashman]], Murray's replacement, was replaced three-quarters of the way through the 1997–98, by [[Roger Neilson]] due to inconsistent team play. Some suggested Clarke's handling of Neilson, who took a medical leave in February 2000 to undergo cancer treatment and was replaced by [[Craig Ramsay]], was disrespectful. Clarke explained "The Neilson situation - Roger got cancer - that wasn't our fault. We didn't tell him to go get cancer. It's too bad that he did. We feel sorry for him, but then he went goofy on us."<ref name="Goofy">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2000/12/22/neilson00.html|title=Clarke claims Neilson 'went goofy'|accessdate=2008-11-10|publisher=[[The Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]]| date=2000-12-22}}</ref> Ramsay guided the team to the Eastern Conference Finals in 2000, but he was fired after a subpar start in 2000-01, being replaced by Clarke's former linemate [[Bill Barber]]. Barber was named coach of the year for 2000-01, however under his watch the Flyers suffered two consecutive first round eliminations, as their 2001 playoffs ended with an 8-0 defeat to Buffalo in Game Six, and their offense was held to just two goals by Ottawa during the 2002 playoffs, and this led to calls for Clarke's dismissal after he fired Barber. Clarke hired [[Ken Hitchcock]] as head coach for the 2002-03 season and Hitchcock remained until Clarke's resignation four years later, guiding the team to the 2004 conference finals.<ref name="Resignation"/>
Following the [[2004–05 NHL lockout]], Clarke signed 6'5" defencemen [[Derian Hatcher]] and [[Mike Rathje]] to four-year and five-year contracts respectively.<ref name="Doomed"/> While the moves were initially praised<ref name="Doomed"/> and even led some to label the Flyers Cup favorites in [[2005–06 NHL season|2005–06]],<ref name="Doomed"/> some suggested Clarke could not compete in the new NHL after the team was eliminated in the first round of the playoffs by Buffalo, a smaller, quicker team that proved to be effective against such slower defencemen as Hatcher and Rathje.<ref name="Resignation"/><ref name="Doomed"/> Such criticisms became louder after a poor start to the following season which led to his resignation.<ref name="Resignation"/>
====Eric Lindros==== Nothing was more controversial during Clarke's time as a general manager than his dispute with [[Eric Lindros]] and his parents, particularly his father Carl who was Eric's agent. The trouble started following the [[1997–98 NHL season|1997–98]] season while negotiating a new contract for Lindros. Clarke threatened to trade him, saying, "If you want to be the highest-paid player in the game or close to it, you've got to play that way."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/classic/biography/s/Lindros_Eric.html|title=Great expectations haunt talented Lindros|publisher=ESPN|author=Bob Carter|date=2004-10-18|accessdate=2011-05-08}}</ref> While Lindros was not traded and he played well during the [[1998–99 NHL season|1998–99]] season, his season was cut short after sustaining a collapsed lung during a game on April 1 against the [[Nashville Predators]].<ref name="Lindros">{{Cite web|url=http://apse.dallasnews.com/contest/2000/writing/over250.news.first.html|title=How it all began|accessdate=2007-07-29|website=The Philadelphia Inquirer|author=Frank Fitzpatrick|year=2000|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070804140431/http://apse.dallasnews.com/contest/2000/writing/over250.news.first.html|archive-date=2007-08-04|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> Lindros' parents criticized team trainer John Worley and claimed Clarke tried to kill their son by trying to put him on a plane back to Philadelphia, which would have been fatal given his condition.<ref name="Lindros"/>
After Lindros criticized Worley in March 2000 for failing to diagnose a concussion<ref name="Lindros"/> (his second of the season),<ref name="88timeline">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/story/2000/11/30/lindros001129.html|title=Eric Lindros timeline|accessdate=2007-07-29|publisher=Canadian Broadcasting Corporation| date=2000-11-30}}</ref> Clarke stripped Lindros of the role of team captain.<ref name="Lindros"/> A few weeks after suffering a third concussion during practice,<ref name="88timeline"/> Lindros returned to the Flyers lineup for Game 6 of the Eastern Conference Finals and sustained his fourth concussion of the season (his sixth in 27 months) during Game 7.<ref name="88timeline"/> Afterwards, Clarke said he did not dislike Eric, but he had a problem with his parents, saying, "If he's going to come back, he can't have his dad calling us and telling us who to trade for and who he wants to play with Eric and who can't play with Eric."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/hockey/news/2001/08/17/lindros_history/|title=Hockey - Eric Lindros' concussion history|work=Sports Illustrated|date=2001-08-17|accessdate=2011-05-08}}</ref> Lindros never played for the Flyers again, as he rejected the Flyers qualifying offer in the off-season and sat out the [[2000–01 NHL season|2000–01]] season. Lindros pushed for a trade to Toronto but that move fell apart at last minute when Clarke and Leafs manager [[Pat Quinn (ice hockey)|Pat Quinn]] could not agree on terms. [http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/hockey/nhl/features/si_stanley_cup/70s/#1974] Clarke finally traded Lindros to the New York Rangers in August 2001. Following the trade, Clarke said, "I don't give a crap whether he ever plays again or if I ever see him again. All he ever did was cause aggravation to our team."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://proicehockey.about.com/b/2006/10/22/bob-clarke-a-farewell-to-hockeys-king-of-quotes.htm|title=Bob Clarke: A Farewell to Hockey's King of Quotes|author=Jamie Fitzpatrick|publisher=About.com|date=2006-10-22|accessdate=2011-05-08}}</ref>
Upon Lindros' retirement in November 2007, Clarke stated that Lindros belonged in the [[Hockey Hall of Fame]]. "Yes, based on his ability to play the game and based on his contributions as a player, I think you have to separate all the crap that went on. Particularly when he played for the Flyers, it was just outstanding, dominant hockey — the first of the huge, big men with small man's skill."<ref name="LindrosHHOF">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/hockey/story/2007/11/08/nhl-clarke-lindros.html?ref=rss|title=Eric Lindros is a Hall of Famer: Clarke | publisher=[[CBC News]] | date=2007-11-09}}</ref>
Lindros and Clarke both played for the Philadelphia Flyers Alumni during the [[2012 NHL Winter Classic#Alumni game|2012 Winter Classic Alumni Game]] on December 31, 2011. The opposing team was the New York Rangers Alumni.<ref name="Alumni">{{Cite news|url=https://www.sbnation.com/nhl/2011/12/31/2672430/winter-classic-alumni-game-eric-lindros-philadelphia-flyers-new-york-rangers|title=Winter Classic Alumni Game: 4 Reasons 2012 Edition Is Better Than Ever | publisher=sbnation | date=2011-12-31}}</ref> Both men acknowledged the game as an opportunity to mend fences.
<blockquote>''(T)his Alumni Game has provided an opportunity to rebuild ... once-burnt bridges. In recent years, Clarke has stated multiple times that he believes Lindros belongs in the Hall of Fame, and Lindros has acknowledged his many disagreements with Clarke and expressed a desire to move on.''<ref name="Alumni"/></blockquote>
==Personal life== Clarke and his family have been long-time residents of [[South Jersey]]. When first playing with the Flyers, Clarke lived in [[Cherry Hill, New Jersey]], later moving to [[Moorestown, New Jersey|Moorestown]] and then [[Haddonfield, New Jersey|Haddonfield]].<ref>Clarke, Bob. [https://njmonthly.com/articles/jersey-living/good-neighbor-policy/ "Good Neighbor Policy; Canadian Bob Clarke was known as Bobby when he arrived as a rookie with the Philadelphia Flyers in 1969. Now the team's senior vice president calls Haddonfield home."], ''[[New Jersey Monthly]]'', November 15, 2000. Retrieved January 1, 2018. "The bars would close up and all the young kids decided to stop over. So we bought a house in Cherry Hill.... But we discovered we liked neighbors, so we sold that and bought a house in Moorestown. The kids, I have four, went to the Friends school there and then the public high school, where they played sports and all. We left for Minnesota and Florida when I had jobs there, then when we came back to the Flyers, we first went back to Moorestown and, after the kids were finished with school, to Haddonfield."</ref>
Clarke and his wife, Sandy, have four children, sons Wade and Lucas and daughters Jody and Jakki. They live in [[Ocean City, New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Hickey|first=Brian|url=http://citypaper.net/articles/2003-10-02/cover.shtml|title=The Ice Man: After all these years do we really know Bobby Clarke?|publisher=[[Philadelphia City Paper]]|date=October 2–8, 2003|accessdate=March 1, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20031116085121/http://citypaper.net/articles/2003-10-02/cover.shtml#|archive-date=2003-11-16|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>

==Legacy== [[File:2010 winter classic pregame.jpg|thumb|250px|right|Clarke prepares for the ceremonial puck drop with [[Bobby Orr]] prior to the [[2010 NHL Winter Classic]].]] On November 15, 1984, Bobby Clarke Night was held at the [[Spectrum (arena)|Spectrum]].<ref name="BCnight">{{cite web|url=http://flyers.nhl.com/club/news.htm?id=435954|title=Great Moments: Bobby Clarke Night|publisher=philadelphiaflyers.com|author=Bill Meltzer|date=2007-11-27|accessdate=2011-05-08}}</ref> The Flyers retired Clarke's #16 jersey and unveiled the [[List of Philadelphia Flyers award winners#Bobby Clarke Trophy|Bobby Clarke Trophy]] which is awarded annually to the Flyers' Most Valuable Player.<ref name="BCnight"/> Three years later Clarke was a first ballot inductee into the [[Hockey Hall of Fame]].<ref name="FlyersHistoryHoF"/> The Flyers created a team Hall of Fame in 1988, and the first two inductees were Clarke and Bernie Parent.<ref name="FlyersHistoryHoF"/> He also played in the [[2012 NHL Winter Classic#Alumni game|2012 Winter Classic Alumni Game]] at [[Citizens Bank Park]] against the New York Rangers alumni.
In addition to his NHL honors, Clarke was appointed an Officer of the [[Order of Canada]] (O.C.). The trophy he won in 1968 and 1969 with the Bombers, given annually to the [[Western Hockey League]]'s top scorer, was renamed the [[Bob Clarke Trophy]]. He was inducted into three more halls of fame, the [[Philadelphia Sports Hall of Fame]] in 2003 as a charter member, [[Canada's Sports Hall of Fame]] in 2005, and the [[Manitoba Hockey Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mbhockeyhalloffame.ca/honoured/players.html?category=7&id=4|title=Players - Robert Earl (Bobby) Clarke|publisher=[[Manitoba Hockey Hall of Fame]]|year=2005|accessdate=2011-05-08|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120607162132/http://www.mbhockeyhalloffame.ca/honoured/players.html?category=7&id=4#|archive-date=2012-06-07|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
===Records=== Clarke finished his career 4th all-time in assists and 11th all-time in points,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.flyershive.com/forums/10345-post1.html<!--Original dead link (http://www.nhl.com/features/clarke_qa101804.html)-->|title=Clarke's goal: Another Cup in Philly|publisher=National Hockey League|date=2004-10-18|accessdate=2011-05-08|quote=When he retired in 1984, Clarke was fourth on the all-time assist list and 11th in overall scoring.}}{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> but he has since fallen to [[List of NHL statistical leaders#Regular season: Assists|25th all-time in assists]] and [[List of NHL statistical leaders#Regular season: Points|44th all-time in points]] ({{As of|2015|7|alt=as of completion of [[2014–15 NHL season]]}}).<ref name="hockeyref">{{cite web | url = https://www.hockey-reference.com/players/c/clarkbo01.html | title = Bobby Clarke NHL & WHA Statistics | work = Hockey-Reference | publisher = Sports Reference LLC | accessdate = 2011-01-01}}</ref> His career [[Plus-minus (ice hockey)|plus-minus]] of +506 is [[List of NHL statistical leaders#Regular season plus-minus|5th all-time]].<ref name="hockeyref"/> His back-to-back 89 assist seasons in 1974–75 and 1975–76 is still the Flyers team record<ref name="PHIseasonleaders"/> and he also owns several other [[Philadelphia Flyers records]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hockey-reference.com/teams/PHI/leaders_career.html|title=Philadelphia Flyers Career Leaders|work=Hockey-Reference.com|publisher=Sports Reference LLC|accessdate=2011-05-08}}</ref> including:

{{lead too short|date=December 2015}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Buck Henry |image=Buck Henry (4970849739).jpg |caption=Henry in 1978 | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1930|12|9}} | birth_place = [[New York City]], U.S. | birth_name = Henry Zuckerman | occupation = Screenwriter, actor, director | spouse = Irene Henry | yearsactive = 1961–present }} '''Henry Zuckerman,''' credited as '''Buck Henry''' (born December 9, 1930), is an [[United States|American]] [[actor]], writer, [[film]] director, and [[television]] director. He has been nominated for an [[Academy Awards|Academy Award]] twice, in 1968 for Best Adapted Screenplay for ''[[The Graduate]]'' and in 1979 for Best Director for ''[[Heaven Can Wait (1978 film)|Heaven Can Wait]]''. ==Early life== Henry was born to a [[American Jews|Jewish]] family[https://www.jewishtampa.com/jews-in-the-news/jews-in-the-news-carrie-fisher-norman-lear-stephen-tobolowsky Tampa Jewish Federation: "Jews in the News: Carrie Fisher, Norman Lear and Stephen Tobolowsky" ] retrieved March 18, 2017 in New York City, the son of silent film actress and star of the original ''[[Gentlemen Prefer Blondes (1928 film)|Gentlemen Prefer Blondes]]'', [[Ruth Taylor (actress)|Ruth Taylor]] (January 13, 1905 – April 12, 1984) and Paul Steinberg Zuckerman (April 15, 1899 – 1965), a retired Air Force brigadier general and [[stockbroker]].{{cite web|url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/29/Buck-Henry.html|title=Buck Henry Biography|publisher=Filmreference.com|date=|accessdate=September 21, 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.time.com/time/sampler/article/0,8599,219497,00.html|title=That Old Feeling: Sweet Smells|publisher=TIME|date=March 21, 2002|accessdate=September 21, 2010}}{{cite web|author=[Displaying Abstract]|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1965/12/04/archives/paul-s-zuckeriyian-broker-here-was-66.html|title=PAUL S. ZUCKERMAN, BROKER HERE, WAS 66 - Obituary - NYTimes.com|publisher=Select.nytimes.com|date=September 5, 2010|accessdate=September 21, 2010}} Henry attended [[Choate Rosemary Hall|The Choate School]] (now Choate Rosemary Hall) and [[Dartmouth College]], where he met [[Bob Rafelson]], and also worked on the ''[[Dartmouth Jack-O-Lantern]]'' humor magazine. From 1959 to 1962, as part of an elaborate hoax by comedian [[Alan Abel]], he pretended to be G. Clifford Prout, the quietly outraged president of the [[Society for Indecency to Naked Animals]], who presented his point of view on talk shows.{{Cite web|url=http://priceonomics.com/the-hoaxster-who-revealed-sad-truths-about-america|title=The Hoaxster Who Revealed Sad Truths About America|first=Zachary|last=Crockett|website=Priceonomics|date=2016-03-16|accessdate=2016-03-20}} ==Television career== Henry's dry humor attracted attention in the entertainment community. He became a cast member on [[television|TV]] programs such as ''[[Steve Allen|The New Steve Allen Show]]'' (1961) and ''[[That Was The Week That Was]]'' (1964–65). He was a co-creator and writer for ''[[Get Smart]]'' (1965–70), with [[Mel Brooks]]. Two of his TV projects had short runs but are fondly remembered by fans: ''[[Captain Nice]]'' (1967) with [[William Daniels]] as a reluctant superhero, and ''[[Quark (TV series)|Quark]]'' (1978), with [[Richard Benjamin]] in command of a garbage scow in outer space. He also played Dr. Victor Rudman, a fractal scientist who dated Murphy, on the "My Dinner With Einstein" episode (1989) of ''[[Murphy Brown]]''. He appeared on the television show ''[[Will and Grace]]'' in 2005. In 2007, he made two guest appearances on ''[[The Daily Show]]'' as a contributor, billed as the show's "Senior Senior Correspondent". He has also appeared as [[Liz Lemon]]'s father, Dick Lemon, in the ''[[30 Rock]]'' episodes "[[Ludachristmas]]" (December 13, 2007) and "[[Gentleman's Intermission]]" (November 4, 2010). In 2011, he appeared in a multi-episode arc of ''[[Hot in Cleveland]]'' as Elka's groom. ==''Saturday Night Live''== Henry hosted NBC's ''[[Saturday Night Live]]'' 10 times between 1976 and 1980, making him the show’s most frequent host during its initial five year run, thus setting a record that held for nearly a decade. This figure does not include the show’s second-season Mardi Gras special, for which he was not in fact credited as host, but rather as one of several guest comedy and musical performers. Because he was featured more prominently than any of the other comedy performers who guested on the special episode (which was broadcast live from within the midst of Mardi Gras events in New Orleans), he is sometimes erroneously considered to have been the host of the program. (This role could be more accurately described as having been filled by musical performer [[Randy Newman]]). It became a tradition during these years for Henry to host the final show of each season, beginning with the 1976-1977 season. Henry's frequent host record would be broken when [[Steve Martin]] made his 11th appearance as host of the show on the finale episode of the 1988-1989 season.Alec Baldwin is now the most frequent male host in ''SNL'' history with 16 episodes from 1990 to 2011. During the October 30, 1976, episode, Buck Henry was injured in the forehead by [[John Belushi]]'s [[katana]] in the [[Saturday Night Live Samurai|samurai]] sketch. Henry's head began to bleed and he was forced to wear a large bandage on his forehead for the rest of the show. As a gag, the members of the ''SNL'' cast each wore a bandage on their foreheads as well. ===Recurring characters on ''SNL''=== *Howard, a sadistic stunt coordinator *Marshall DiLaMuca, father of Bill Murray's character Todd in [[The Nerds]] sketches *Mr. Dantley, the straight man and frequent customer to Samurai Futaba's ([[John Belushi]]) many businesses. *Uncle Roy, a single, [[pedophilic]] babysitter who disguises his attempts at molesting the children he is watching (played by [[Gilda Radner]] and [[Laraine Newman]]) as games. ===Celebrity impersonations on ''SNL''=== *[[Charles Lindbergh]] *[[John Dean]] *[[Ron Nessen]] ==Film and stage career== Henry has appeared in more than 40 films including ''[[The Graduate]]'', ''[[Candy (1968 film)|Candy]]'', ''[[Catch-22 (film)|Catch-22]]'', ''[[Taking Off (film)|Taking Off]]'', ''[[The Man Who Fell to Earth (film)|The Man Who Fell to Earth]]'', ''[[Gloria (1980 film)|Gloria]]'', ''[[Eating Raoul]]'', ''[[Aria (film)|Aria]]'', ''[[Tune in Tomorrow]]'', ''[[Defending Your Life]]'', ''[[The Player (film)|The Player]]'',Henry's cameo in ''[[The Player (film)|The Player]]'' had him (playing himself) pitching a 20-years-later sequel to ''[[The Graduate]]'', which Henry later claimed led to real-life interest in such a project from some studios. ''[[Short Cuts]]'', and ''[[Grumpy Old Men (film)|Grumpy Old Men]]''. He co-directed ''[[Heaven Can Wait (1978 film)|Heaven Can Wait]]'', the 1978 remake of ''[[Here Comes Mr. Jordan]]'', and appeared in the film as an officious angel, reprising the character originally played by [[Edward Everett Horton]]. His many writing credits include ''[[The Graduate]]'', ''[[Candy (1968 film)|Candy]]'', ''[[The Owl and the Pussycat (film)|The Owl and the Pussycat]]'', ''[[What's Up, Doc? (1972 film)|What's Up, Doc?]]'', ''[[Catch-22 (film)|Catch-22]]'', ''[[The Day of the Dolphin]]'', ''[[Protocol (film)|Protocol]]'', and ''[[To Die For]]''. Henry shared an [[Academy Awards|Oscar]] nomination with [[Calder Willingham]] for their screenplay for ''[[The Graduate]]'' (1967). He received a second shared Oscar nomination, this time for Best Director of 1978’s ''[[Heaven Can Wait (1978 film)|Heaven Can Wait]]'', which he co-directed with the movie’s star [[Warren Beatty]]. In 1997, Henry was the recipient of the [[Austin Film Festival]]'s Distinguished Screenwriter Award. His Broadway credits include the 2002 revival of ''[[Morning's at Seven]]''. Off-Broadway in July 2009, he starred opposite [[Holland Taylor]] in ''Mother'', a play by Lisa Ebersole.{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/129098-Buck+Henry+and+Holland+Taylor+Cast+in+Ebersole's+Mother|title=Buck Henry and Holland Taylor Cast in Lisa Ebersole's play, ''Mother''|publisher=Playbill.com|date=May 11, 2009|accessdate=September 21, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090515024637/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/129098-Buck+Henry+and+Holland+Taylor+Cast+in+Ebersole's+Mother#|archive-date=May 15, 2009|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} ==Filmography== ===Film=== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2015}} {{Use Indian English|date=October 2015}} {{Infobox person | name = Chandramukhi Basu | image = Chandramukhi Bose.jpg | image_size = 100px | caption = | birth_date = 1860 | birth_place = [[Dehradun]], [[British India]] | death_date = 1944 | death_place = Dehradun, British India | occupation = Educationist | spouse = Pandit Keswaranand Mamgayen | alma_mater = [[Scottish Church College|Duff College]]
[[University of Calcutta]] }} '''Chandramukhi Basu''' ({{lang-bn|চন্দ্রমুখী বসু}}; 1860–1944), a [[Bengali Christian]] from [[Dehradun]], which was located in the (then known as) [[United Provinces of Agra and Oudh]], was one of the first two female graduates of the [[British Empire]]. In 1882, along with [[Kadambini Ganguly]], she passed the examination of the bachelor's degree in arts from [[University of Calcutta]], India. Their formal degrees were handed during the convocation of the University in 1883. ==Early life== The daughter of Bhuban Mohan Bose, she passed the First Arts examination from Dehradun Native Christian School in 1880.Sengupta, Subodh Chandra and Bose, Anjali (editors), 1976/1998, ''Sansad Bangali Charitabhidhan'' (Biographical dictionary) Vol I, {{Bn icon}}, p152, {{ISBN|81-85626-65-0}} At that time [[Bethune College|Bethune School]], to which shewanted to enter; did not admit non-Hindu girls, and as such she had to be admitted at the First Arts (F.A.) level in Reverend [[Alexander Duff (missionary)|Alexander Duff]]'s Free Church Institution (now the [[Scottish Church College]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishchurch.ac.in/College%20History02.pdf |title=Glimpses of college history |publisher=www.scottishchurch.ac.in|accessdate=2009-03-10|last=|first=}} In 1876, because of the discriminatory official stances towards gender, she had to be given special permission to appear for the F.A. examination. As the only girl to appear for the examination that year, she had ranked first, but the university had to hold a series of meetings to decide whether her results could be published. Before Kadambini Ganguly, Chandramukhi Basu had already cleared her Entrance Examination in 1876, although the university refused to enlist her as a successful candidate. Only the university's changed resolution in 1878 allowed her to study furtherManna, Mausumi, (2008) ''Women's Education through Co-Education: the Pioneering College'' in ''175th Year Commemoration Volume''. Scottish Church College, page 108{{cite web | url =http://www.telegraphindia.com/1130402/jsp/opinion/story_16721248.jsp#.UVpP8zNTCSo | title = Teaching girls to take on an unequal society | accessdate = 2013-04-02 | last = | first = | work = The Telegraph, Calcutta | publisher = The Telegraph, 2 April 2013 }} After she passed her F.A. examination, she moved to Bethune College for the degree course, along with Kadambini Ganguly. After her graduation, she was the only (and first) woman to pass MA from the [[University of Calcutta]], and the British empire in 1884. ==Career== She started her career as a lecturer in Bethune College (it was still part of Bethune School) in 1886. The college was separated from the school in 1888. She became the principal, thus becoming the [[Firsts in India|first]] female head of an undergraduate academic establishment in South Asia. She retired in 1891 because of bad health and spent the rest of her life in Dehradun. ==Sisters== Two of her sisters, Bidhumukhi and Bindubasini, were also renowned. Bidhumukhi Bose and Virginia Mary Mitra (Nandi), graduating in 1890, were among the earliest women medical graduates from Calcutta Medical College. Thereafter, Bindubasini Bose graduated from Calcutta Medical College in 1891.Bose, Anjali (editor), ''Sansad Bangali Charitabhidhan'' (Biographical dictionary) Vol II, 1996/2004,{{Bn icon}}, p215, 219, {{ISBN|81-86806-99-7}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{cite book |last=Chakraborty |first=Rachana |year=2012 |chapter=Bethune College |chapter-url=http://en.banglapedia.org/index.php?title=Bethune_College |editor1-last=Islam |editor1-first=Sirajul |editor1-link=Sirajul Islam |editor2-last=Jamal |editor2-first=Ahmed A. |title=Banglapedia: National Encyclopedia of Bangladesh |edition=Second |publisher=[[Asiatic Society of Bangladesh]]}} * [http://www.scottishchurch.ac.in/College%20History02.pdf History of Scottish Church College] {{Bengal Renaissance}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Basu, Chandramukhi}} [[Category:Indian Anglicans]] [[Category:Scottish Church College, Calcutta alumni]] [[Category:Bethune College alumni]] [[Category:Indian women academics]] [[Category:University of Calcutta alumni]] [[Category:University of Calcutta faculty]] [[Category:Scientists from Dehradun]] [[Category:Bengali people]] [[Category:1860 births]] [[Category:1944 deaths]] [[Category:Indian women medical doctors]] [[Category:Scientists from Uttarakhand]] [[Category:Indian women educational theorists]] [[Category:20th-century Indian medical doctors]] [[Category:19th-century Indian medical doctors]] [[Category:19th-century Indian women scientists]] [[Category:19th-century Indian scientists]] [[Category:20th-century Indian women scientists]] [[Category:20th-century Indian scientists]] [[Category:19th-century Indian educational theorists]] [[Category:20th-century Indian educational theorists]] [[Category:Women scientists from Uttarakhand]] [[Category:Scholars from Uttarakhand]] [[Category:Medical doctors from Uttarakhand]] [[Category:Women educators from Uttarakhand]] [[Category:Educators from Uttarakhand]] [[Category:Scholars from Dehradun]]
