O. Hirschfelder, 78, Atom Bomb Developer, March 31, 1990][http://www.nap.edu/openbook.php?record_id=4961&page=191 National Academies Press:Biographical Memoirs V.66 (1995), JOSEPH OAKLAND HIRSCHFELDER, BY R. BYRON BIRD, CHARLES F. CURTISS, AND PHILLIP R. CERTAIN] Robert Oppenheimer assembled a team at the Los Alamos Laboratory to work on plutonium gun design [[Thin Man (nuclear bomb)|Thin Man]], that included senior engineer [[Edwin McMillan]] and senior physicists [[Charles Critchfield]] and Joseph Hirschfelder. Hirschfelder had been working on [[internal ballistics]]. Oppenheimer led the design effort himself until June 1943, when Navy [[Captain (United States O-6)|Captain]] [[William Sterling Parsons]] arrived took over the Ordnance and Engineering Division and direct management of the "Thin Man" project.{{sfn|Hoddeson|Henriksen|Meade|Westfall|1993|pp=83–84}} Hirschfelder was a member of the [[National Academy of Sciences]], a group leader in [[theoretical physics]] and ordnance at the [[Los Alamos National Laboratory|Los Alamos Atomic Bomb Laboratory]], chief phenomenologist at the nuclear bomb tests at Bikini, the founder of the Theoretical Chemistry Institute and the Homer Adkins professor emeritus of chemistry at the [[University of Wisconsin]]. Hirschfelder was also a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He was awarded the [[National Medal of Science]] from President [[Gerald Ford]] “for his fundamental contributions to atomic and molecular quantum mechanics, the theory of the rates of chemical reactions, and the structure and properties of gases and liquids.” The [[National Academies Press]] called him "one of the leading figures in theoretical chemistry during the period 1935-90"." In 1991 an award was established in his name by the University of Wisconsin's Theoretical Chemistry Institute - the annual Joseph O. Hirschfelder Prize in Theoretical Chemistry.[http://www.chem.wisc.edu/content/joseph-o-hirschfelder-prize University of Wisconsin, Joseph O. Hirschfelder Prize] He was an elected member of the [[International Academy of Quantum Molecular Science]].[http://www.iaqms.org/members.php Members of IAQMS] His book ''Molecular theory of gases and liquids'' is an authoritative text on the kinetic theories of gases and liquids. [[File:Thin Man plutonium gun bomb casings.jpg|right|thumb|"Thin Man" plutonium gun test casings at [[Wendover Air Force Base|Wendover Army Air Field]], as part of [[Project Alberta]] in the [[Manhattan Project]]. "[[Fat Man]]" casings can be seen behind them.]] == Biography == Hirschfelder completed his undergraduate studies at the [[University of Minnesota]] from 1927 to 1929 and at [[Yale University]] from 1929 to 1931. Hirschfelder received doctorates in [[physics]] and [[chemistry]] from [[Princeton University]] under the direction of [[Eugene Wigner]], [[Henry Eyring (chemist)|Henry Eyring]] and [[Hugh Stott Taylor]]. He worked as a Postdoctoral fellow with [[John von Neumann]] for a year after his PhD at the [[Institute for Advanced Study]]. In 1937, he moved to [[University of Wisconsin]] and stayed there until retirement in 1981, except during the world war II. == Awards and distinctions == * 1953 - elected to the [[National Academy of Sciences]]http://www.nasonline.org/member-directory/deceased-members/54552.html * 1959 - elected to the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] * 1965 - elected to the Norwegian Royal Society * 1966 - the [[Peter Debye Award]] from the [[American Chemical Society]] * 1966 - the [[Alfred Charles Glyn Egerton|Alfred C. Egerton]] Gold Medal of the [[Combustion Institute]]https://www.combustioninstitute.org/resources/awards/alfred-c-egerton-gold-medal/ * 1976 - the [[National Medal of Science]]https://www.nationalmedals.org/laureates/joseph-o-hirschfelder * 1978 - honorary degree from [[Marquette University]] * 1980 - honorary degree the [[University of Southern California]] * 1981 - elected to the [[Royal Society of Chemistry]] of Great Britain * 1981 - the Silver Medal of the [[American Society of Mechanical Engineers]] Joseph O. Hirschfelder Prize is awarded annually by the Department of Chemistry at the University of Wisconsin in honor of Hirschfelder.https://www.chem.wisc.edu/content/joseph-o-hirschfelder-prize == References == {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== * {{MathGenealogy|id=170801}} {{Winners of the National Medal of Science}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Hirschfelder, Joseph O.}} [[Category:1911 births]] [[Category:1990 deaths]] [[Category:American physicists]] [[Category:American chemists]] [[Category:American nuclear physicists]] [[Category:Manhattan Project people]] [[Category:Nuclear weapons scientists and engineers]] [[Category:Members of the United States National Academy of Sciences]] [[Category:University of Wisconsin–Madison faculty]] [[Category:International Academy of Quantum Molecular Science members]]

{{For|the album of the same name|Lea Salonga (album)}} {{Philippine name|Imutan|Salonga}} {{Infobox musical artist |honorific_prefix = |name = Lea Salonga |honorific_suffix = [[Order of Lakandula|KLD]] |image = LeaSalonga.jpg |image_size = |caption = Salonga after a performance of ''[[Once on This Island]]'' |background = solo_singer |birth_name = Maria Lea Carmen Imutan Salonga[https://web.archive.org/web/20090920051546/http://www.leasalonga.com/press/Lea_Bio.doc "Lea Salonga Biography"], archived August 31, 2013 |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1971|2|22}} |birth_place= [[Manila]], [[Philippines]][https://familysearch.org/pal:/MM9.3.1/TH-1-14229-75905-12?cc=1686086&wc=M8GJ-5Z9:129556201,130218201,178290802 Lea Salonga's Birth Certificate]{{Primary source-inline|date=September 2014}} |genre = [[Pop music|Pop]], [[Original Pilipino Music|OPM]], [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]], [[musical theatre]] |occupation = [[Singer]], [[actress]] |label = [[Atlantic Records|Atlantic]], [[Arista Records|Arista]], [[Capitol Records|Capitol]], [[EMI Philippines]], Musiko, [[Sony Music Entertainment|Sony Music Philippines]], [[Warner Music Group|WEA]], [[Walt Disney Records|Walt Disney]] |website = {{URL|http://www.leasalonga.com/}} }} '''Maria Lea Carmen Imutan Salonga''', [[Order of Lakandula|KLD]] ({{IPAc-en|ˈ|l|eɪ|ə|_|s|ə|ˈ|l|ɒ|ŋ|ɡ|ə}}; born February 22, 1971) is a [[Filipino people|Filipina]] singer and actress best known for her roles in [[musical theatre]], for supplying the singing voices of two [[Disney Princess]]es, and as a recording artist and television performer. At age 18, she originated the lead role of Kim in the musical ''[[Miss Saigon]]'', first in the [[West End theatre|West End]] and then on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]],[http://www.broadway.com/gen/Buzz_Star_File.aspx?ci=23104 "Broadway.com Star Files"], accessed March 10, 2016 winning the [[Laurence Olivier Award|Olivier]] and [[Theatre World Award]]s, and becoming the first Asian woman to win a [[Tony Award]].Gioia, Michael. [http://www.playbill.com/article/im-hoping-there-is-a-shift-says-lea-salonga-on-diversity-and-the-united-colors-of-this-season-com-354199 "'I'm Hoping There is a Shift', Says Lea Salonga On Diversity and the 'United Colors' of This Season"], Playbill, July 24, 2015, accessed April 30, 2016 Salonga is the first Filipino artist to sign with an international record label ([[Atlantic Records]] in 1993). She is also the first [[Philippines|Philippine-based]] artist to have received a major album release and distribution deal in the United States, and one of the best-selling Filipino artists of all time, having sold over 19 million copies of her albums worldwide.{{cite web| url=http://www.celebritiesph.com/actresses/filipino-actresses/lea-salonga.html| title=Wow Celebrities: Lea Salonga| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071019042247/http://www.celebritiesph.com/actresses/filipino-actresses/lea-salonga.html| archivedate=2007-10-19| df=}}{{Citation needed|date=December 2017}} Salonga was the first actress of Asian descent to play the roles of [[Éponine]] and [[Fantine]] in the musical ''[[Les Misérables (musical)|Les Misérables]]'' on Broadway.[https://web.archive.org/web/20070808195117/http://www.lesmis.com/pages/news/newsdetail.php?newskey=52 "''Les Misérables'': Tony Award winner to join the cast as Fantine"], ''Les Misérables'', Cameron Mackintosh Overseas Limited, 2007, accessed July 11, 2016; and [http://www.broadway.com/buzz/96323/tony-winner-lea-salonga-gets-early-start-as-new-fantine-of-les-miz "Tony Winner Lea Salonga Gets Early Start as New Fantine of ''Les Miz''"], Broadway.com, March 2, 2007, accessed July 11, 2016Wingfield, Garth. [http://www.newyork.com/articles/broadway/10-stars-who-broke-barriers-on-broadway-17674 "10 Stars Who Broke Barriers on Broadway"], NewYork.com, June 25, 2014, accessed July 11, 2016 She also portrayed Éponine and Fantine, respectively, in the musical's 10th and [[Les Misérables: 25th Anniversary Concert|25th anniversary]] concerts in London. She provided the singing voices of two official Disney Princesses: [[Princess Jasmine|Jasmine]] in ''[[Aladdin (1992 Disney film)|Aladdin]]'' (1992) and [[Mulan (Disney character)|Fa Mulan]] in ''[[Mulan (1998 film)|Mulan]]'' (1998). She was named a [[Disney Legend]] in 2011 for her work with [[The Walt Disney Company]].[http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/entertainment/08/21/11/lea-salonga-becomes-disney-legend Lea Salonga becomes a Disney legend] Salonga starred as Mei-li in the 2002 Broadway version of ''[[Flower Drum Song]]''. She has played numerous other stage, film and TV roles in the US, the Philippines and elsewhere. She has toured widely in the title role of ''[[Cinderella (musical)|Cinderella]]'', among other roles, and as a concert artist. From 2015 to 2016, she returned to Broadway in ''[[Allegiance (musical)|Allegiance]]'', and from 2017 to 2018 she appeared in the Broadway revival of ''[[Once on This Island]]''. ==Life and career== ===1971–1989: Early life and career === María Lea Carmen Imutan Salonga was born at [[Medical Center Manila]] in [[Ermita]], [[Manila]], to Feliciano Genuino Salonga, a naval [[Rear admiral]] and shipping company owner (1929–2016),[http://www.rappler.com/entertainment/news/120909-lea-salonga-father-feliciano-dies "Lea Salonga's father Feliciano Salonga dies"], ''Rappler'', February 1, 2016 and his wife, María Ligaya Alcantara, ''née'' Imutan. She spent the first six years of her childhood in [[Angeles, Philippines|Angeles City]] before moving to [[Manila]].{{cite web|url=http://www.filipinoweb.com/leasalonga.html|title=Filipino Web: Lea Salonga|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090307111532/http://www.filipinoweb.com/leasalonga.html|archivedate=March 7, 2009}} Her brother, [[Gerard Salonga]], is a conductor.[http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1G2-3444200168.html "Salonga, Lea 1971–"], ''Contemporary Theatre, Film and Television'', Encyclopedia.com, 2005, accessed November 4, 2015 She made her professional debut in 1978 at the age of seven in the musical ''[[The King and I]]'' with Repertory Philippines. She played the title role in ''[[Annie (musical)|Annie]]'' in 1980 and appeared in other productions such as ''[[Cat on a Hot Tin Roof]]'', ''[[Fiddler on the Roof]]'', ''[[The Sound of Music]]'', ''[[The Rose Tattoo|The Rose T]]'', ''[[The Goodbye Girl]]'' (1982), ''[[Paper Moon (film)|Paper Moon]]'' (1983) and ''[[The Fantasticks]]'' (1988). In 1981, she recorded her first album, ''[[Small Voice]]'', which was certified gold in the Philippines.[https://d23.com/walt-disney-legend/lea-salonga/ "Lea Salonga"], [[D23 (Disney)|D23]], accessed October 21, 2015 In 1985, she and her brother took part in the [[Metro Manila Popular Music Festival#The 8th Metro Manila Popular Music Festival|eighth Metro Manila Popular Music Festival]] as the interpreters for the song entry titled "Musika, Lata, Sipol at La La La" which was composed by Tess Concepcion. During the 1980s, Salonga also had several television projects through [[GMA Network|GMA Radio Television Arts]] where she worked as a [[child actor]] and [[teen idol]]. After the success of her first album, from 1983 to 1985, she hosted her own musical television show, ''Love, Lea'', and was a member of the cast of [[German Moreno]]'s teen variety show ''[[That's Entertainment (TV series)|That's Entertainment]]''. She acted in films, which included the family-oriented ''Tropang Bulilit'', ''Like Father, Like Son'', ''Ninja Kids'', ''Captain Barbell'' and ''Pik Pak Boom''. As a young performer, Salonga received a Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences ([[FAMAS Awards|FAMAS]]) award nomination for Best Child Actress, and three [[Aliw Award|Aliw Awards]] for best child performer in 1980, 1981 and 1982. She released her second album, ''[[Lea (album)|Lea]]'', in 1988. She also opened for, and performed with, international acts such as [[Menudo (band)|Menudo]] and [[Stevie Wonder]] in their concerts in Manila in 1985 and in 1988, respectively.{{cite web|url=http://www.tv.com/lea-salonga/person/92158/biography.html|title=TV.com: Lea Salonga}} She finished her secondary education in 1988 at the [[O. B. Montessori Center]] in Greenhills, San Juan, Metro Manila,{{cite web|url=http://www.newsflash.org/2004/02/ht/ht005316.htm|title=Article on Preciosa Soliven, with notes on Lea Salonga}} where she was a Bergamo 1 Student and an active participant in school productions. She also attended the [[University of the Philippines]] College of Music's extension program aimed at training musically talented children in music and stage movement. A college freshman studying biology at the [[Ateneo de Manila University]] when she auditioned for ''[[Miss Saigon]]'', she intended to have a medical career. Later, in between jobs in New York, she took two courses at [[Fordham University]]'s [[Lincoln Center]]. === 1989–1992: ''Miss Saigon'' and ''Aladdin'' === In 1989 Salonga was selected to play Kim in the debut production of the musical ''[[Miss Saigon]]'' in London. Unable to find a strong enough East Asian actress/singer in the United Kingdom, the producers scoured many countries looking for the lead.{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9D0CE6DB163AF934A25750C0A967958260|title=New York Times: "Theater: The Iron Butterfly within Miss Saigon," March 1991 | work=The New York Times | first=Alex | last=Witchel | date=March 17, 1991 | accessdate=May 7, 2010}} For her audition, the then 17-year-old Salonga chose to sing [[Alain Boublil|Boublil]] and [[Claude-Michel Schönberg]]'s "[[On My Own (Les Misérables)|On My Own]]" from ''[[Les Misérables (musical)|Les Misérables]]'' and was later asked to sing "Sun and Moon", impressing the audition panel.{{cite web|url=http://www.antiqbook.com/boox/bookco/707188.shtml|title=Behr, Edward and Mark Steyn, The Story of Miss Saigon, New York: Arcade Publishing, 1991}} Salonga has sometimes credited "On My Own" as the starting point of her international career.Pierce, Scott. [http://archive.sltrib.com/story.php?ref=/sltrib/lifestyle/53820026-80/song-changed-byutv-cardon.html.csp "Stars reveal song that changed their lives in new TV series"], ''[[The Salt Lake Tribune]]'', March 30, 2012, accessed July 10, 2016Gelfand, Janelle. [http://www.cincinnati.com/story/entertainment/2016/04/23/disney-princess-dancing-queen-lea-salonga-charms-pops/83387668/ Review: Disney princess to 'Dancing Queen,' Lea Salonga charms with Pops], ''[[Cincinnati.com]]'', April 26, 2016 She competed for the role with childhood friend and fellow Repertory Philippines performer [[Monique Wilson]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5avKuNGQ_NE|title=YouTube: "Too Much for One Heart" history explained by Lea Salonga in her concert}} Salonga won the lead role, while Wilson was named her [[understudy]] and given the role of the bar girl Mimi.{{cite web| url=http://moniquewilson.com/bio2.php| title=Monique Wilson Biography| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080104130955/http://moniquewilson.com/bio2.php| archivedate=2008-01-04| df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.asiaweek.com/asiaweek/magazine/2000/0218/people.html|title= A Broadway belle hits the books again}} For her performance as Kim, Salonga won the 1990 [[Laurence Olivier Award]] for Best Performance by an Actress in a Musical. When ''Miss Saigon'' opened on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] in 1991, she again played the role of Kim,{{cite news|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9C0CE3D8163AF931A35750C0A966958260| title=New York Times: "'Miss Saigon' finds home on Broadway". March 1990 | work=The New York Times | first=Mervyn | last=Rothstein | date=March 2, 1990 | accessdate=May 7, 2010}} winning the [[Drama Desk]], [[Outer Critics Circle Award|Outer Critics Circle]] and [[Theatre World Award|Theatre World]] Awards and becoming the first woman of Asian descent to win a [[Tony Award]].Lee, Ashley. [http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/features/asian-actors-onstage-lea-salonga-842293 "Asian Actors Onstage: Lea Salonga, Phillipa Soo Sound Off on Broadway Representation, Cultural Perceptions"], ''The Hollywood Reporter'', November 24, 2015 In 1993 and 1996, she returned to play Kim on Broadway. In 1999, she was invited back to London to close the West End production, and in 2001, at the age of 29 and after finishing the Manila run of the musical,{{cite news|url=http://archives.cnn.com/2000/ASIANOW/southeast/12/03/philippines.miss.saigon/index.html|title=CNN: "Musical ''Miss Saigon'' opens in the Philippines, home of its leading ladies" | accessdate=May 7, 2010 | date=December 4, 2000}} Salonga returned to Broadway to close that production.{{cite news|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2001/SHOWBIZ/Arts/01/16/miss.saigon/index.html|title=Miss Saigon star returns | first= | last= |work=CNN |date=January 16, 2001 | accessdate=May 7, 2010}} In 1990, Salonga performed in a homecoming concert in [[Manila]] entitled ''A Miss Called Lea''.{{cite web| url=http://www.filmreference.com/film/69/Lea-Salonga.html|title=Film Reference: Lea Salonga}} She also received a Presidential Award of Merit from [[President of the Philippines|President]] [[Corazon Aquino]].Porcalla, Delon. [http://www.philstar.com/headlines/2014/12/06/1399540/aquino-confers-awards-33-outstanding-pinoys "Aquino confers awards on 33 outstanding Pinoys"], ''The Philippine Star'', December 6, 2014, accessed March 10, 2016 In 1991, she was named as one of ''People'' magazine's [[50 Most Beautiful People]].[http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20122069,00.html "Beautiful Through the Years"], ''People'' magazine, May 12, 1997, Vol. 47, No. 18, accessed October 21, 2015 In 1992, she performed the singing voice of [[Princess Jasmine]] in [[The Walt Disney Company|Disney's]] animated film ''[[Aladdin (1992 Disney film)|Aladdin]]''. === 1993–1996: ''Les Misérables'', films and other musicals === In 1993, Salonga played the role of [[Éponine]] in the Broadway production of ''[[Les Misérables (musical)|Les Misérables]]''.[http://www.broadway.com/buzz/96178/lea-salonga-to-replace-daphne-rubin-vega-in-les-miserables/ "Lea Salonga to Replace Daphne Rubin-Vega in Les Misérables"], Broadway.com, January 3, 2007, accessed March 10, 2016 She performed the song "[[A Whole New World]]" from ''Aladdin'' with [[Brad Caleb Kane|Brad Kane]] at the 65th Annual [[Academy Awards]] in [[Los Angeles]],{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LPmK0_1l-Bg|title=YouTube: "A Whole New World" at the Oscar Awards}}{{cite book|last=Wiley|first=Mason|title=Inside Oscar: The Unofficial History of the Academy Awards|year=1996| publisher=Ballantine Books| location=New York|isbn=0-345-40053-4|page=883|edition=5|author2=Damien Bona}} where the song won an [[Academy Awards|Oscar]], having already won a [[Golden Globe Award]]. That same year, she released her self-titled international debut album with [[Atlantic Records]], which had modest sales in the US but went platinum in the Philippines and sold 3 million copies worldwide. In 1994, Salonga played in various musical theatre productions in the Philippines and [[Singapore]],{{cite book| url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aIu8qmB_wxEC&pg=PA4&lpg=PA4&dq=lea+salonga+age+of+seven+biography#PPA4,M1| title="The Right Way to Sing" by Linda Marquart: Lea Salonga Biography|isbn=978-1-58115-407-8|author1=Marquart| first1=Linda|last2=Salonga|first2=Lea|date=2005-04-01}} such as Sandy in ''[[Grease (musical)|Grease]]'', Eliza Doolittle in ''[[My Fair Lady]]'' and the Witch in ''[[Into the Woods]]''. Back in the US in 1995, Salonga played the role of Geri Riordan, an 18-year-old adopted [[Vietnamese American]] child in the [[Hallmark Hall of Fame]] [[TV movie]] ''[[Redwood Curtain (film)|Redwood Curtain]]'', which starred [[John Lithgow]] and [[Jeff Daniels]]. She then flew back to the Philippines to star with Filipino matinée idol [[Aga Muhlach]] in the critically acclaimed film ''[[Sana Maulit Muli (film)|Sana Maulit Muli]]'', which gave her a second Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences ([[FAMAS Awards|FAMAS]]) award nomination, this time for Best Actress. She played the role of Éponine in the 10th anniversary production of ''Les Mis'' called ''[[Les Misérables: The Dream Cast in Concert]]'' at London's [[Royal Albert Hall]]. In 1996, Salonga was in ''Les Misérables'' once again as Éponine in the London production of the musical, then continued on to perform the role in the musical's US national tour. In the Philippines in 1999, and again in 2000, she played Sonia Walsk in ''[[They're Playing Our Song]]''."Lea Salonga, at Home and Playing Her Own Song", ''International Herald Tribune'', August 15, 2000 === 1997–2004: Recordings, concerts, TV and ''Flower Drum Song'' === From 1997 to 2000, Salonga did recordings and concerts in the Philippines and another engagement in London, in addition to a few returns to ''Miss Saigon'' in London and on Broadway. In 1997, she released ''[[I'd Like to Teach the World to Sing (album)|I'd Like to Teach The World to Sing]]'' (recordings from her childhood days) to gold sales in the Philippines.{{cite web|url=http://www.mp3.com/albums/528331/summary.html|title=MP3.com: Lea Salonga – I'd Like to Teach the World to Sing}} That recording was followed by ''[[Lea... In Love]]'' in 1998{{cite web|url=http://www.inquirer.net/saturday/jan99wk1/spc_main.htm|title=Philippine Daily Inquirer: "10: The Best of 1998"}} and ''[[By Heart (Lea Salonga album)|By Heart]]'' in 2000, with both albums reaching multiple platinum status in the Philippines. In 1998, she again lent her voice to a major Disney animated film, singing [[Mulan (Disney character)|the title character]] in ''[[Mulan (1998 film)|Mulan]]'', also providing the character's singing voice in the 2004 sequel, ''[[Mulan II]]''. At the age of 28, Salonga moved to New York City, purchasing her own apartment (which she still owns up to at least 2013).{{cite news |last=Gonzalez |first=Bianca |date=29 September 2013 |title=Lea Salonga on life as Kim, Sonia, Eponine, wife & mom |url=http://www.philstar.com/sunday-life/2013/09/29/1239225/lea-salonga-life-kim-sonia-eponine-wife-mom |newspaper=Philippine Star |access-date=28 March 2015 }}
{{cite book|author=Kevin L. Nadal and the Filipino-American National Historical Society Metropolitan New York Chapter|title=Filipinos in New York City|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=V6HOBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA8|date=30 March 2015|publisher=Arcadia Publishing| isbn=978-1-4671-2308-2|page=8}} She participated in the 1998 tribute concert to Sir [[Cameron Mackintosh]] in London called "Hey Mr. Producer: The Musical World of Cameron MacKintosh", where she did numbers from several of his musicals.{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/39076.html|title=Playbill: "Judi Dench, Bernadette Peters to join Lea Salonga in London benefit"}}{{cite web|url=http://www.albemarle-london.com/Archive/ArchiveShow.php?Show_Name=Hey%20Mr%20Producer!|title=Albermarle of London: Hey Mr. Producer!|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100917091433/http://albemarle-london.com/Archive/ArchiveShow.php?Show_Name=Hey%20Mr%20Producer!|archivedate=2010-09-17|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.broadway.com/gen/Buzz_Story.aspx?ci=33514|title=Broadway.com: "DVDs: Mackintosh's Salad Days"}} She also performed in four concerts: ''The Homecoming Concert'', ''The Millennium Concert'', ''The Best of Manila'' and ''Songs from the Screen'' – the last two being benefit shows. Salonga returned to Manila in ''Miss Saigon'', staged at the [[Cultural Center of the Philippines]] at the end of 2000.{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/54813.html|title=Playbill: "She will be Miss Saigon again: Salonga to be Kim in October Manila mounting"}} After a last stint in ''Miss Saigon'' for its closing on Broadway in 2001, Salonga recreated the role of [[Lien Hughes]] originally played by [[Ming-Na|Ming-Na Wen]] in the [[soap opera]] ''[[As the World Turns]]''. After completing her contract that year, she was asked to return to the role in 2003.{{cite web|url=http://www.soapcentral.com/atwt/theactors/salonga.php|title=Soap Central: Lea Salonga}}{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/77449.html|title=Playbill: "Lea Salonga does double-duty: "Flower Drum Song" and "As the World Turns""|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080612033059/http://www.playbill.com/news/article/77449.html|archivedate=2008-06-12|df=}} She guested on Russell Watson's ''The Voice'' concert, narrated for the television special ''My America: A Poetry Atlas of the United States'', and appeared on the Christmas episode of the TV medical drama ''[[ER (TV series)|ER]]'', playing a patient with [[lymphoma]]. In 2002, Salonga returned to Broadway to play the leading role of Mei-li, a Chinese immigrant in a reinterpretation of [[Rodgers and Hammerstein]]'s ''[[Flower Drum Song]]'' opposite [[Jose Llana]]. This was after the reinvented musical had a run at the Mark Taper Forum in Los Angeles in 2001 with Salonga playing the role{{cite web| url=http://www.broadway.com/gen/Buzz_Story.aspx?ci=5316|title=Broadway.com: "Lea Salonga confirmed for Flower Drum Song"}}{{cite web| url=http://asianweek.com/2002_10_11/feature.html|title=Asian Week: "Making Musical History"}}{{cite web|url=http://www.playbill.com/news/article/72773.html|title=Playbill: "The 'Flower' blooms: Rodgers and Hammerstein's 'Drum Song' opens Oct. 17 on Broadway"}} and in 2002 winning Lead Actress in a Musical from the Los Angeles theatre [[Ovation Awards]].Ehren, Christine. [http://www.playbill.com/article/big-river-napoli-milionaria-big-winners-at-las-ovation-awards-com-109948 "''Big River, Napoli Milionaria'' Big Winners at L.A.'s Ovation Awards"], ''Playbill'', November 25, 2002 The Salonga-led Broadway revival cast album was nominated for a 2004 [[Grammy Award]] for Best Musical Show Album.{{cite web|url=http://www.theatermania.com/content/news.cfm/story/4167|title=Theater Mania: "Five musical show albums nominated for Grammy Awards"}} Salonga's performance was received positively by theatre critics in New York, and she received a nomination for ''Distinguished Performance'' from the [[Drama League Award|Drama League]], among other honors.[http://www.broadwaytovegas.com/dramaleague.html The 2003 Drama League Nominees and Winners"], BroadwayToVegas.com, 2003 Between the 2001 Los Angeles and 2002 [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]] productions of ''Flower Drum Song'', she performed in a non-musical theatrical production for the first time, playing the role of Catherine in the stage play ''[[Proof (play)|Proof]]'' in [[Manila]]. This was followed by a major concert, ''The Broadway Concert'', at the [[Philippine International Convention Center]]. She also sang at the 56th [[Tony Awards]] with [[Harry Connick, Jr.]], [[Peter Gallagher]] and [[Michele Lee]] in a number paying tribute to [[Richard Rodgers]]. In 2003 to 2004, Salonga did her first "all-Filipino" concerts in [[Manila]] called ''Songs from Home'', which later won her an Aliw Award as ''Entertainer of the Year''.[http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/129221/three-icons-reunite-in-the-legends-and-the-classics/amp "Three icons reunite in 'The Legends and the Classics'"], Inquirer.net, October 5, 2013, accessed December 3, 2016 In 2003, she performed in several concerts at the [[Mohegan Sun]] hotel in Connecticut. web|url=http://www.carouselpinoy.com/leacaroustar.html|title=Carousel Pinoy: Lea Salonga}} Later in 2004, she played Lizzie in the Manila production of the musical ''[[Baby (musical)|Baby]]'', which [http://www.rappler.com/entertainment/news/151597-lea-salonga-fun-home-eric-kunze "Lea Salonga on ''Fun Home'', working with Eric Kunze"], [[Rappler]], November 11, 2016 Salonga recorded a song called "Wished That I Could Call You" that was included in the charity compilation album ''Children In Need'', released in March 2014.{{cite web|last=Cerasaro|first=Pat|title=Lea Salonga & Sierra Boggess Record New Tracks For Charity Compilation Album|url=http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Lea-Salonga-Sierra-Boggess-Record-New-Tracks-For-Charity-Compilation-Album-20131024|work=24 October 2013|publisher=Broadway World|accessdate=February 11, 2014}}{{cite web|title=Lea Salonga's song 'Wish That I Could Call You' just sounds incredible now. Out in March.|url=https://twitter.com/DanLauraCurtis/status/421389459599261697|work=10 January 2014| publisher=DanLauraCurtis Twitter account|accessdate=February 11, 2014}} Also in 2014–15, she toured in Asia and North America with [[Il Divo]].Henry, Alan. [http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/BWW-Interviews-Lea-Salonga-Talks-Il-Divo-Tour-Allegiance-Miss-Saigon-and-More-20140522 "BWW Interviews: Lea Salonga Talks Il Divo Tour, ''Allegiance, Miss Saigon'', and More!"], BroadwayWorld, May 22, 2014 In mid-2015, she headlined her own concert series in Australasia.Cerasaro, Pat. [http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Lea-Salonga-Kicks-Off-Australia-New-Zealand-Tour-Today-20150723 "Lea Salonga Kicks Off Australia & New Zealand Tour Today"], Broadwayworld.com, July 24, 2015 Salonga reprised her role as Kei Kimura in the 2015–16 Broadway production of ''Allegiance''.[http://www.broadwayworld.com/article/Breaking-News-Tony-Winner-Lea-Salonga-Telly-Leung-to-Join-George-Takei-in-ALLEGIANCE-on-Broadway-20150312 Breaking News: Tony Winner Lea Salonga & Telly Leung to Join George Takei in ALLEGIANCE on Broadway!] Broadway World, Retrieved March 13, 2015 [[Charles Isherwood]] wrote in ''[[The New York Times]]'' of her performance: "Her voice retains its plush beauty, and her culminating first act solo, "Higher" ... is perhaps the show’s musical highlight."Isherwood, Charles. [https://www.nytimes.com/2015/11/09/theater/review-allegiance-a-musical-history-lesson-about-interned-japanese-americans.html?_r=0 "Review: ''Allegiance'', a Musical History Lesson About Interned Japanese-Americans"], ''The New York Times'', November 8, 2015 Salonga guest-starred on the April 18, 2016 season finale of the American television series ''[[Crazy Ex-Girlfriend (TV series)|Crazy Ex-Girlfriend]]''.{{cite news| last1=Dimalanta| first1=Ces|title=Lea Salonga to appear, sing in ‘Crazy Ex-Girlfriend’ finale|url=http://www.mb.com.ph/lea-salonga-to-appear-sing-in-crazy-ex-girlfriend-finale/| accessdate=January 15, 2016|work=[[Manila Bulletin]]|date=January 12, 2016}} She played Helen Bechdel in the international premiere of ''[[Fun Home (musical)|Fun Home]]'' in November 2016 in Manila.Hetrick, Adam. [http://www.playbill.com/news/article/lea-salonga-will-star-in-fun-home-international-premiere-372281 "Lea Salonga Will Star in ''Fun Home'' International Premiere"], ''Playbill'', November 18, 2015 A review in [[ABS-CBN News]] said that she "delivers a finely tuned performance, utilizing her prodigious stage presence to provide the cold and dark shadings to erstwhile peppy scenes with her subtle stares and held back emotions. ... [In] "Days by Days" ... she finally lets go of all the resentment and repressed anger of a woman stuck in a marriage built on a lie. Yet there is dignity in her breakdown ... Salonga pulls it off with such clarity, both musically and emotionally, that it's difficult not to be moved.Bunoan, Vladimir. [http://news.abs-cbn.com/life/11/11/16/review-superb-fun-home-cast-moves-audience-to-tears "Review: Superb ''Fun Home'' cast moves audience to tears"], ''ABS-CBN News'', November 12, 2016 In 2016 she won two more Aliw Awards, one for Best Major Concert in a Foreign Venue and her second Entertainer of the Year award.[http://news.abs-cbn.com/entertainment/12/02/16/lea-salonga-wins-entertainer-of-the-year-at-aliw-awards-2016 "Lea Salonga wins Entertainer of the Year at Aliw Awards 2016"], ''ABS-CBN News'', December 2, 2016 The following year, Salonga was one of the coaches on ''The Voice Teens''.{{Cite web |url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/entertainment/03/01/17/lea-excited-to-mentor-teens-on-the-voice |title=Lea excited to mentor teens on 'The Voice' |date=March 1, 2017 |publisher=''[[ABS-CBN News]]'' |publication-date=April 17, 2017}} Also in 2017, she released an album, ''Bahaghari: Lea Salonga Sings Traditional Songs of the Philippines'', with songs sung in several languages spoken in the Philippines.Gans, Andrew.[http://www.playbill.com/article/from-carnegie-hall-to-miss-saigon-and-the-oscars-tony-winner-lea-salongas-5-most-memorable-nights-onstage "From Carnegie Hall to Miss Saigon and the Oscars, Tony Winner Lea Salonga's 5 Most Memorable Nights Onstage"], ''Playbill'', February 9, 2018 Salonga portrayed Erzulie in 2017–2018 in the Broadway revival of ''[[Once on This Island]]'' at [[Circle in the Square Theatre]], where she received critical praise for her vocal performance.{{cite web| last=Stasio| first=Marilyn| title=Variety review of ''Once on This Island''|url=https://variety.com/2017/legit/reviews/once-on-this-island-review-broadway-1202629232|date=December 3, 2017}}
{{cite news| title=''Once on This Island'' on Broadway holds 'Filipino Night' |url=http://usa.inquirer.net/10529/island-broadway-holds-filipino-night |work=Philippine Daily Inquirer |location=Philippines |date=March 2, 2018 |access-date= March 22, 2018}}Hetrick, Adam. [http://www.playbill.com/article/lea-salonga-will-depart-broadways-once-on-this-island "Lea Salonga Will Depart Broadway's ''Once on This Island''"], ''Playbill'', May 8, 2018 == Personal life == On January 10, 2004, Salonga married Robert Charles Chien, a Chinese-Japanese managing director of an entertainment software company in Los Angeles, California, whom she met while doing ''[[Flower Drum Song]]''.Santiago, Erwin. [http://www.pep.ph/celeb/spotlight/11692/lea-salonga-returns-to-broadway-and-les-miserables "Lea Salonga returns to Broadway and ''Les Misérables''], Philippine Entertainment Portal, January 5, 2007, accessed March 10, 2016{{cite web|url=http://www.newsflash.org/2002/08/sb/sb002334.htm|title=Newsflash.org: "A Whole New World for Lea Salonga"}} They have a daughter, Nicole Beverly Chien, who was born in 2006, named after Salonga's late [[mother-in-law]], Beverly.{{cite web|url=http://www.catholicdigest.com/article/print/this-is-the-career-god-has-chosen-for-me|title=Catholic Digest: "This is the career God has chosen for me"}} Nicole has performed alongside Salonga in the musical ''Matilda''.{{Cite news|url=https://www.rappler.com/entertainment/news/181848-lea-salonga-daughter-nicole-chien-joins-matilda-musical-cast|title=Lea Salonga's daughter Nicole Chien joins cast of ''Matilda the Musical''|work=Rappler|access-date=July 11, 2018}} She is also an avid [[video game]] enthusiast, and has mentioned her love for the hobby in several of her print articles.{{cite web| url=http://gmtristan.com/lea-salonga-is-a-gamer/|title=Le Salonga is a gamer}} She resides in the Philippines and the United States.{{cite book|author=Mary Yu Danico| title=Asian American Society: An Encyclopedia|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gZleBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA697|date=3 September 2014|publisher=SAGE Publications| isbn=978-1-4522-8189-6|page=697}} On October 15, 2010, Salonga was appointed [[FAO Goodwill Ambassador|Goodwill Ambassador]] for the [[Food and Agriculture Organization]] of the [[United Nations]] (FAO).{{cite news|title=Lea Salonga is UN goodwill ambassador in fight vs hunger|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/entertainment/10/15/10/lea-salonga-un-goodwill-ambassador-fight-vs-hunger|accessdate=January 15, 2016|work=[[ABS-CBNnews.com]]|agency=[[Agence France-Presse]]|publisher=[[ABS-CBN Corporation]]|date=October 15, 2010}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20130115094900/http://www.fao.org/getinvolved/ambassadors/ambassadors/ambassadors-leasalonga/en/ FAO Goodwill Ambassador website] == Voice and musical ability == Salonga has a [[soprano]]{{cite web|title=Actress and singer Lea Salonga to perform|url=http://www.goshen.edu/news/2013/04/16/actress-and-singer-lea-salonga-to-perform-at-goshen-college-on-april-23/|publisher=Goshen College|accessdate=2 September 2014}} [[vocal range|range]] from D3 to C6.{{cite web |url=http://newsflash.org/chat/leanight.htm |title=A Night with Lea Salonga |date=1 August 1997 |publisher=newsflash.org |accessdate=2012-09-24}}{{primary_source-inline |date=September 2012}} She has been praised for control over her powerful vocals which can evoke a wide array of emotion and soundscapes.{{cite web |url=http://www.theaureview.com/adelaide/live-review-lea-salonga-adelaide-festival-theatre-adelaide-10-06-12 |title=Live Review: Lea Salonga – Adelaide Festival Theatre, Adelaide (10 June 2012) |date=11 June 2012 |first=Sosefina |last=Fuamoli |publisher=theaureview.com |accessdate=2012-09-24}} In her popular music releases, Salonga has sung "simple love songs", which is common in traditional [[Original Pilipino Music]].{{cite web |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/by-heart-mw0001032816 |title=Lea Salonga: By Heart |publisher=[[AllMusic]] |accessdate=2012-09-24}} In both Disney princess singing roles, Salonga showcases her head tones which reach up to F5.{{cite web |url=http://www.musicnotes.com/sheetmusic/mtdFPE.asp?ppn=MN0057034&ref=google |title=Reflection Lea Salonga Digital
